DIV1.P: THE Different Widows: OR, Intrigue All-A-Mode.
As it is Acted at the New Theatre in Little Lincolns-Inn-Fields.
Vade, sed incultus qualem decet Exulis esse.
LONDON: Printed for Henry Playford in the Temple▪Change, and Bernard Litot at the Middle-Temple-Gate, Flstreet.

DIV1.HEAD: To the Right Honourable THE COUNTESS OF SALISBURY.
DIV1.P:
WHEN Heroick Vertue presents it self to our View in such a conspicuous Character as Your Ladiships, 'tis impossible to be silent, tho' we can never hope to Express the beautiful Excellence, whilst on a barren Theme Invention might be wanting; Your Ladiship's Life speaks it self, and to give a bare Relation of Your Actions is a Panegyrick. That unalterable Fidi∣lity to your Lord, and constant Suffering with him; That unshaken Resolution of preserving his Name and Memory entire, and that generous and tender regard of his Rela∣tions, gives an Idea of those Noble Roman Wives, whose exalted Merit, in every Change of Life, was still the same, Triumphant in Adversity, and Constant in Prosperity; tho' I want▪ Skill to give the Praises due to such Divine Perfe∣ctions; Yet I hope at least this may Excite some
more able and successful Pen, whose soaring Genius may prove worthy the delightful. Task, and may instruct the Age to Come, by Your renowned Example: Where else shall we find so Active and so Improving a Mind in the Female Sex, to tempt the numerous Hazards of the Sea, passing undaunted over the Raging Billows in search of use∣ful Curiosities, whilest others have thought it a sufficient accoun of their time to have been busied in Scandal and Intrigue: You have travel'd the Alps, and made the Tour of Rome, (once the Capital City of the World) Inlarging the Knowledge and Illustrating the Honour of our Happy Nation.

I blush to lay so mean a Trifle at the Feet of so Nice a Judge, but 'tis the Prerogative of the Great to protect the most Distress'd: Let its Defects be made up with the profound Respect and Zeal the Author has for Your Ladyship, and the endless Wishes made for Your continual Happiness, that you may live to see Your Charming Son long possess his Honour, and increase That Race which always Adorn'd our Kingdom, that all Felicities may constantly attend the Series of Your Noble Life. This and much more than can be Exprest, is the Prayer of

CLOSER.SALUTE: MADAM, Your Honours most Obedient, and most Humble Servant,

LG.L: WHAT Arts have we not try'd? What Labour ta'en,
To Reconcile You to Our House again?
One while, in Mournful Tragedy we strove,
T' Inspire You with the tender Thoughts of Love;
But never cou'd your drowsy Passions move.
You'r all of late such Rigid Stoicks grown,
Ev'n poor Monimia now might weep alone;
Whilst you most Phylosophically frown,
Since Flanders, and the Fighting Trade came up,
'Tis thought Effeminate one Tear to drop.
Damn Tragedys says one, I hate the strain,
I got a Surfeit of 'em last Campaign;
Come, prithee let's be gon to Drury-Lane.
Thither in Crouds ye flock'd to se, Sir Harry,
Or any Fop dress'd All-A-Mode de Paris;
So ▪twas but Droll, it never could Miscarry.
Finding your Palates so much out of tast,
We fairly ventur'd for a lucky Cast;
And Wit being grown by Prohibition scrce,
Regal'd you here too with an Irish Farce.
'Twas Farce, and therefore pleas'd You; for a while,
Our Teague, and Nicodemus made you smile:
That Lure grown stale, we since are orc'd to fill,
With Supplemental Epilogue, our Bill:
For, having us'd you still to something new,
You now begin t' expect it as your due;
And ne'er reflect that these penurious Times,
Our Bards cannot afford to give us Rhymes.
How have I trudg'd about, from day, to day,
Barely to beg a Prologue to our PLAY.
Morn, after Morn, I've sought, yet could not get
(If Life had layn at Stake) one Drachm of Wit;
You'd swear I'd gon a Begging in the Pit.
From thence to the Old Exchange, and there I mt
One of Frinds, who's turn'd a thristy Cit:
A sight of aay the Poet Run,
Just smttiics a grim Serjeant shun▪
Help, help, cry'd I, Sir, or We're all undone.
Begar, id all my Art di il, me ave swore
Never to make the Englis Verses more;
But 'cause You be de Friend, if You vad know
Vad rate de Stock, or de Debenture go,
Me'll rell you dat. I thank You Sir, said I,
But, I have no Occasion now to bay.
From him, streight to St. Lawrence-Lane I went,
You ot Necessity knows no Restraint;
And there (most horrible to View) I saw
Such Magazines of Court-Hand, and the Law,
So nigh resembling those which cost us dear
(In Hall of Westminster) but the last Year,
I thought no Friend to th' Play-House could live there;
But as the Proverb has't, do right to th' Devil;
The Kentish Yeoman, Faith, was very Civil:
It was Term-Time, and e was to attend
A Judge, so bid me not on him depend.
From thence, it being past the time of Noon,
With nimble Steps I hy'd to the Half-Moon:
Don Quixot had been there, but he was gon.
Nt speeding there, to Will's I took my round,
B not one Poet there was to be found,
Except the Author of the Country Wife,
But aith, I dr'st not Wake him for my Life:
Least his Plain Dealing Muse should let you hear
Such Stinging Truths, you'd not know how to bear,
And make you (in Pet) our House forsear.

DIV1.HEAD: ADVERTISEMENT.
DIV1.P: England's Black Tribunal: Or, The Tryal of King Charles the First, by the Pretended Court of Justice. With the last Dying Speeches of that Pious Monarch's most Faithful and ever. Loyal Subjects, price Bound 2 s.

Pills to Purge Melancholly. Being a Collection of all the Choicest Old and New Ballads, and Scotch Songs: Fitted to all Humours, with Tunes to each of them, for the Violin or Flute, in Four Books; The last Inti∣tuled, Apollo's Feast: Or, Wits Entertainment. Containing all the plea∣sant Prologues and Epilogues, Spoke and Writ by Jo. Haynes, Mr. Pinkeman, Cave Vnderhill, and other Excellent Comedians. As also the Mountebank's Speech, by Mr. Ward. The price of these Four Books Eight Shillings and Six Pence Bound.
The Excellent Tragedy of King Saul. Written by a late Person of Ho∣nour, for the promoting of Vertue, Loyalty, and Friendship. Price Stitch'd, 1 s. 6 d.
The Tragedy of Oroonoko. Writ by Mr. Sthern. Price Stitch't, 1 6 d.
The She Gallants, and Heroick Love. By the Honourable George Grenville Esq; Each Stitch't, 1 s. 6 d.
Lover's Luck. By Captain Dilks. Price 1 s.

With all sorts of Vocal and Instrumental Musick Books, and Books on all other Subjects to be had of Henry Playford, at his Shop in the Temple-Change, or at his Dwelling-House in Arundel-Street in the Strand: Where is to be had the Dancing-Master Compleat, and the Apollo's Banquet; the First and Second Part of the Division-Violin; being the best Books ever yet Published, for that Instrument.

DIV3.HEAD: The SCENE an Anti-Chamber.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Sir James in his Night-Gown, and Servants.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: TO begin with thee in Heroicks. How wears the Day!

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Past Ten, an't please your Honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: What an indolent Morning have I had? Re∣pose creates fresh Appetite, renews Desire, and makes the Day, and what's sweeter than the Day, the Evening relish.—Who has been here?

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Two Masks, Five Governante's, half a score maim'd Watchman▪ three Pulvil Women, four handsome Sempstresses, and a Poet, which out∣stays all the rest with a Dedication; he has been here Eleven times, Nine of which I deny'd him of my own accord, the other Two by your Com∣mand.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Enow in all Conscience; bring him up. What can the Mortal find to say of me? Ten to one he publickly declares, I [Exeunt Serv.] am a very sober Gentleman, the Hope of my Family, the Ornament of my Country, &c. Damn'd Lyes by Jupiter and Juno, and the rest of the Heathen Gods and Goddesses; for I remember, I paid Two Guinea's for swearing Christian Oaths but last Night.

SP.SPEAKER: Poet.
SP.P: I have not yet been so happy.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: What can you pretend then? Do you take my Character from Truth, or Fancy? If from Truth, it will upon Examination e call'd a Dedication most Impudent▪ for it will tell me, I am a Man of a loose Con∣versation, without Morals, without Honour or Conscience, Debauch'd in my Life, Debilitated in my Person and Fortunes: Now what the Devil had you to do, to proclaim all this?

SP.SPEAKER: Poet.
SP.P: Bless me! Honourable Sir, there's nothing like it; be pleas'd to Read.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Then there's nothing true: Are you poor?

SP.SPEAKER: Poet.
SP.P: Like the rest of my fraternity, my worthy Patron.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Yet, if Nature has been lavish on thee, and qualify'd thy Mind for pleasing Numbers, never debase thy Muse to groveling Flattery, nor meanly wait at great Men's Doors, for the small Alms which they bestow on Wit; Starve rather in a Noble Pride; like Butler and most of that unhappy tuneful strain, ourt the unconstant Goddess in any Form but Poetry▪ and she may chance to Smile; therefore quit Scribling, if thou'd't be either Rich or Wise, there's Advice for your Dedication, and Money for your Poetry.

SP.SPEAKER: Poet.
SP.P: Twenty Guinea's! I am confounded with your Honour's Wit and Bounty.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Praises of either will displease me; wait on him down.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Pox take him, he shou'd never have come up, if I had thought this; I dare swear he has not Twenty more left in the World.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Boy, fill me a Glass of Mountain Wine, to prevent Thinking, that Antipathy to pleasure.

DIV3.P: 'Tis well my Grave Friend I am arm'd with the sprightly Juice, for I expect a long Reproof for last Nights Sallies.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: Sir James I grieve!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Prithee do not begin with that abominable solemn look: Why our Years are almost equal; our Affections agree, and how the Devil camour Constitutions to differ: You can live without a Mistress, I can∣not, you love to go to Bed sober, I hate it Valentine; these things must be rectified on your side, or we part, that's certain.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: Do you know you lost Five Hundred Pound at Play last Night.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Yes, and intend to pay it, soon as I can get the Writings out of the Country that I may raise more Money.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: That ever a Man of your Sense▪

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P:
Shou'd set up ootmen to keep their Coaches, and bring him∣self to walk a foot, shou'd have such a covetous Itch in him, for spight of
a seeming Generosity, the desire of Play Springs from a base Root, even from Avarice; for if Diversion were intended, small Stakes wou'd do, and the Game please as well, the time pass more chearfully; for great Stakes create Passion, Passion Spleen, the Spleen several Distempers, a thousand Mischiefs, loss of Estate, Family, and at last Untimely Death; there I think I have made as good an Harangue against Gaming as you cou'd have,—Boy, fill me some Wine, I deserve it.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: This will break your Mothers Heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Then there falls a swinging#Joynture, which I intend to Mort∣gage before-hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: What not Drest yet, thou lazy Thing?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: By thy Air thou hast layn rough all Night.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: 'Twas wholly devoted to obliging Mrs. Draul, till she durst not go Home poor Soul, but retir'd to Lady Gayloves, I have slept an hour since, and recruited, pall'd Affection, come prethee let us go there, I know 'tis thy first Visit, which made me call on thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Alone with Mrs. Draul all Night!

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: No, there was Mrs. Tyewell, but she never spoils Company.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: Such as you preserve Reputation.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: You must know, besides my seeing Mrs. Draul, I have another Design at Lady Gayloves, which if I succeed in, Fortune, as you call her, shall be my Deity as long as I live.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: He a Design at Lady Gayloves, sure there's too great an Antipathy between us two, than to allow we should agree in any thing; I have a Plot too, which I'll instantly go about, least Chance guide such a Wretch to prevent me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Come Val, shall we have thy Philosophical Company thither.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: I have other Business, Sir James: Good morrow, and if good Coun∣cil is not thrown away upon you, Reflect e're it be too late, be advis'd and Reclaim.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Well, let sober Fools say what they please, to me a Regular Life wou'd be a perfect Course of Physick, and I wou'd as soon be Drench'd, Cupp'd and Scarified by a Doctor to prevent a Fit of Sickness I dream'd of, as live wisely and sparingly now, because Seven Years hence, my For∣tunes may oblige me to it.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: The Preaching Rogues that wou'd debauch thy Principles, never tasted Life; Business and Interest is all they mind, and telling over Gold the greatest satisfaction they know.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Unenvied let them count their mouldy Heaps, and boast of dull Content, we follow Pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Ay, Wine and Women for us.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Draul.
SP.P: Dear Creature, how shall I Reward thy Kindness?

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: Oh Madam I'll leave it to your Generosity. I know not what my Lady will say, but I'd run greater hazards to serve Mrs. Draul.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Draul.
SP.P: Fear not, for if nothing else will do, this Diamond-Ring will Mollifie her.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: I must needs say, it has a very persuasive Look.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Draul.
SP.P: I must Compound with my Wretch of a Husband before I go Home, or I shall be most unmercifully Us'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: 'Tis a sad Age we live in, that a Gentlewoman can't pertake a little harmless Mirth, but she must suffer under these Apprehensions for it. Hark, the Bell Rings, I'm wanted, this is my Lady's hour to Dress, and I must go Air her Scarf and Snuff-box for the Fatigues she perpetually indures makes her very careful of her Health.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Draul.
SP.P: I'll retire and expect good News.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE Changes.
DIV3.STAGE: Lady Gaylove at her Toylet. Enter Lucy.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Gay.
SP.P: Well, give me my things, Lord, I am infinitely glad Furbe∣lows are out, they had such an unsizeable Air, one cou'd not distinguish a Woman of Quality from an Hostess.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: The Ladies will be surpriz'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Gay.
SP.P: Ay, they'll think me a Monster, tho' it has been an Esta∣blish'd Fashion in France these ten days. What Presents to day Lucy?

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: Lady Smirk has sent a pair of China Jarrs; the very wonder of their kind; My Lady Cringe a Charming Sett of Plate for your Toylet, and my Lady Bounce half a dozen Bottles of right Nants Brandy.
Why won'd she offer to send me such a Present publickly? She's the most indiscreet Woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: Madam I took care and hurry'd it to your Closet before any body guess'd what 'twas.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Gay.
SP.P: Mighty well thought on, and I must own, tho' Lady Bounce has faults, she's good natur'd and a tolerable Companion.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: Then Madam here's Mrs. Draul when you please to see her.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Gay.
SP.P:
Dear Angel why does she stay from my Arms, Lucy I'll have no body held in an Impertinent Discourse now, since I've learn'd to put on my Complexion a Bed, let every one come up without scruple. How broke Mrs. Draul loose from her Wife Teacher thus early, he us'd to
hold forth against Patches and Vizards, and spin his Morning Lecture to a much later hour?

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: Oh Madam, she had the Misfortune to stay out with Mr. Careless a little longer then usual last night, and dur'st not go home to the Brute her Husband; tho' your Ladyship was a Bed, I took pitty and kept her here, or Heaven knows what she wou'd have done.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Gay.
SP.P: Ridiculous; pray who taught you pitty, this is fine indeed, my Reputation shall be injur'd for the sake of your compassionate Nature, must my House be the Refuge of Runagate Wives, I shall be pointed at, 'tis Imprudently done; not that I'd persuade Mrs. Draul to go home against her will, or that I find fault with her leaving the hideous Fellow, but to stay at my House all Night, why if it shou'd be known, I shou'd be undone.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: Dear Madam be pacify'd, I'll ingage my Life it shall be a Secret, she's sorry for the accident, and only stays till she can get some Friend to make up the Matter with Mr. Draul; in the mean time she begs you'll wear this, as a Sign you forgive her.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Gay.
SP.P: 'Tis prettily Sett▪ Well, I excuse you both, but don't let her come near me, that if I am ask'd, I may swear I han't seen her, I wou'd not have the least Cloud on my Reputation, what Letters wait my Lei∣sure?

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: Half a hundred Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Gay.
SP.P: Give them me, ha, here's one from the Rich Jew, he's an Obliging Man, whatever he gains by Usury he lays out in Intrigue; one from my Lord Courtall, he Dyes for the Charming Lady Loveman; well, next to an affair of one's own, 'tis the greatest pleasure in the World to be Confidantè to another.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Sir Anthony and his Wife.
Lady Gaylove throws down her Letters on the Toylet.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Gay.
SP.P: Dear, Dear, Lady Loveman!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Lov.
SP.P: I tast no Joy, till I come to see you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ant.
SP.P: Nay truth is, Cocky never lets me rest till I bring her hither▪ Your Ladyship has some particular Charm.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Good Morning Ladies.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Good Morrow Widdow.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Gay.
SP.P: Dear Sir James Correct that rough Style of Yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: I'm in a rough humour; Five Hudred Guineas lost last Night at my Lord Winnalls, a Damn'd deal of Mony Faith.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Lov.
SP.P: If my good Wishes might prevail, you shou'd have better luck.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Whilst the Fair Smile on me I defy Fortune, and have forgot my III Chance already.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Gay.
SP.P: What kind Planet Reigns to day that I am blest with Dandle's absence, I never mist him before when Sir James was in Company?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: I rose sooner than usual this Morning to escape being alone with him, when he finds me gon he'll ramble hither, for besides his Friend∣ship to me he has a great passion for Your Ladyship.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Gay.
SP.P: Out on him Despicable Creature. Lucy, when he comes, watch him and guard my China from being broke, for 'tis the most busie, most troublesom, and most unlucky of all two Legg'd Animals.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: I love his hard Words, they often divert the Spleen; then when we are Drinking and Quarrelsome, without▪scruple we can kick him down Stairs; when upon a frolick, not a Man can break Windows or abuse the Watch better.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: And at last he is sure to be taken and attone for all, but Whist, here he comes.

SP.SPEAKER: Dandle.
SP.P: So, so, I have caught you by Jove; Sir James, the Glory of In∣triegue, and Lady Loveman, the Queen of Beauty, Lady Gaylove the God∣dess of Pleasure, the Superstratum of Delight: What, here are Letters from every Corner of the World, fill'd with Encomiums on your Wit and Shape, and Face and Air, &c. ha,

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Gay.
SP.P: Good Mr. Dandle, be persuaded to be well Bred and keep your Distance

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: From the Ladys Secrets.

SP.SPEAKER: Dandle.
SP.P: Hold let me Read this, it begins with, Dear, Witty, Gad I'm almost Jealous, in spight of all her Railings, she'll Marry at last, and then I shall hang my self.

DIV3.STAGE: Lady Gaylove and Dandle strive for the Letters, he pulls down the Powder.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Gay.
SP.P: Sir James why don't you breed a Tame Monkey to follow you, I am confident it wou'd be a much better Companion and do less Mischief?

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: I thought to have seen Mrs. Draul here.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Gay.
SP.P: What means Mr. Careless?

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: VVith your leave, Madam, I wou'd speak with her.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Gay.
SP.P: I hear she is broke out in perfect Rebellion, and do you think I wou'd hazard my to Entertain her, on my VVord un∣less she return to her Hnsband I'll never see her more.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: is Impossible!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Gay.
SP.P: Sure I may be believ'd, I tell you I wou'd not have such a blot in my Character, such a breach in my Decorum, as to Receive a Wife into my House in Disobedience to her Husband, for the third part of the Universe.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Charming Angel, how danger∣ous 'tis to Gaze upon you! Sir Anthony, you are the happyest Man in the whole World.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ant.
SP.P: Do you really think so? Nay Cocky is a fine piece of Flesh and Blood, and I know my Happiness.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: She is a Lovely Creature.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Lov.
SP.P: Sir James you are a Rambler, and think your self oblig'd to flatter every new Face.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ant.
SP.P: See, she has a Tongue in her Head, ten to one 'twill be too hard for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Dandle.
SP.P: Gad the Old Tost makes a good Pimp.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: I'll wait on you, and persuade you to think better of me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ant.
SP.P: And so she shall, or I'll forfeit my Coat of Arms.

SP.SPEAKER: Dandle.
SP.P: And I an't out of my Augury, if thou wou'dst not ra∣ther have them inlarg'd, I know what Sir James wou'd be at, but what can this Old Fellow mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Sir Anthony, tho' we have held some Correspondence about grave Affairs, we have seldom met to Converse—prithee Knight let's be better acquainted.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ant.
SP.P: With all my heart, by'r Lady I have not seen a Civiler Gen∣tleman, I love him because he respects my VVife; pray do us the Honour to call when you come in the City, and if I be not at home, Cocky will Entertain you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Lov.
SP.P: To please nowne Deary, I'll do any thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Dan.
SP.P: Gad I'll banter this Categorical Gentleman: Sir Knight, a word in your Ear, do you really intend to leave that Mark Anthony alone with Your Cleopatra?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Dog be Silent and prevent many Stripes.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ant.
SP.P: Why what if I do, I think Sir James a very worthy Person, and he says such fine things of Cocky, I can't tell how to make him amends, but tell me, he is not used to Corrupt Vertuous Women is he?

SP.SPEAKER: Dan.
SP.P: No not so neither, but Sir James is handsom and Women are frail, and by your Physiognomy—

DIV3.STAGE: Sir Anthony draws his Chair nearer, Dandle removes it again, and throws Sir Anthony down.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ant.
SP.P:
I cou'd find in my heart to beat the Coxcomb, I am much pro∣vok'd, only good Company restrains me, but by'r Lady. [Aside.] I'll not
take much pains to bring Sir James and my Wife together. I thank Mr. Dandle for that Hint.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Mr. Draul Drest like an Essence Woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Essence.
SP.P: Bless your good Honours, the finest Essence in the whole World, here's a Scent wou'd revive the Dead.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Gay.
SP.P: Pray who are you, did any body here send for thee, I shou'd as soon think thou sold'st Oysters▪ as Essence, I never saw so unpromising an Air.

SP.SPEAKER: Essence.
SP.P: Madam, your Ladyships own Essence Woman order'd me to wait on You.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Gay.
SP.P: Has she sent me the Water she promis'd me, Extracted from onquils in the Bud.

SP.SPEAKER: Essence.
SP.P: She begs your Pardon as she is a living Woman, she cou'd not help it; Lady Sweetlack had it, and gave her Ten Guineas for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Gay.
SP.P: Let her never dare to come into my sight agen, sure I cou'd have given Ten Guineas as well as my Lady Sweetlack; I did not send my Diamond Necklace, my Gold Watch and Monkeys Chain, to buy Indian Bargains; Gentlemen I ask your Pardons for my Passion, but Passion be∣comes a Lady sometimes.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Oh extreamly!

SP.SPEAKER: Essence.
SP.P: My Jezebel is not among these, I must search farther I am sure she is in the House, and now I have put on the outside of Pro∣phaness, I wou'd willingly wear it to some purpose.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Gay.
SP.P: Lucy take something of her.

SP.SPEAKER: Essence.
SP.P: Hum; I think this House has infected me, for I am almost tempted to Evil, I like the Damsel well, what if instead of Cor∣recting my Wife, I make mery with a Mrs.—I think 'twere best, but if I see my Hariotry, anger will prevail for this time; however I can slip a Piece of Gold into her hand, and she'l guess my meaning when I call agen.

SP.SPEAKER: Essence.
SP.P: Mrs. Lucy, I have a secret Beauty, a perfect Charm, but I wont name it before Company. I've heard my Lady Gaylove's humour, have me into some Closet and I'll show it and tell its wonderful qualities.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Gay.
SP.P: I like this Woman strangely, have her in.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Madam I'll wait on you tomorrow at Two precisely.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ant.
SP.P: Unfortunate People as we are, we Dine abroad tomorrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Next day then I wont fail.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ant.
SP.P: Alass! then we shall be teiz'd with a great deal of Ill Company at Home, but I'll send word when Cocky and I am at leasure to entertain You sutable to your Merit.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: This is your doing Rascal, but I'll be even.

SP.SPEAKER: Dan.
SP.P: Dear Sir James, I thought nothing but to Jest a little.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Thou wert born the Enemy of all Mankind.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Gay.
SP.P: And the Antipathy of all Women.

SP.SPEAKER: Dan.
SP.P: Severe enough in all Conscience, and yet I dare swear; you all love me.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Mrs. Draul pursued by her Husband, dress'd for the Essence Woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Lov.
SP.P: Bless us, what's here?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dra.
SP.P: Oh save me from the Monster▪

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dra.
SP.P: No Monster till you made me one Minks; is this the effect of my Instruction, my early Advice, and my late Examination. Avant tho Daughter of Levity, of Pride, Deceit and Prophaness: I suspected your Haunts, and have spoil'd your Market; now let your Gallant provide you a Lodging for good and all, but he'll go near to leave you in the Lurch, when the Husband will Maintain you no longer.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Gay.
SP.P: Out of my Doors you wicked Creature and don't disturb my House with Your Brauls.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: I thought Madam you were to have been believed, or I had pre∣vented all this.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Gay.
SP.P: It must be Lucy's Contrivance for I am Innocent, Oh the horrid Slut, I am Distracted, she shall out of my House this Minute, I'll hear no body speak in her behalf. I know that Mrs. Draul was here? Oh abominable!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ant.
SP.P: By'r Lady my Neighbour Draul, ha, ha, ha, I cannot chuse but Laugh at his Disguise tho' I pitty his Misfortune.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Dr.
SP.P: Fly thon Witch of Endor, or I shall be forc't to do thee a Mischief, I dare say nothing to Lady Gaylove lest I come here my self on the like business.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dr.
SP.P: I'll not go till I am Justified; I have done you no wrong.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: I feel an Inclination in my self to turn Knight Errant, and Relieve this Distressed Female.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Gay.
SP.P: Such Indecorums Committed in my House I shall never En∣joy my self agen.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Lov.
SP.P: Have Patience Dear Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Gay.
SP.P: 'Tis impossible, my Reputation, my Reputation.

SP.SPEAKER: Da. Egad,
SP.P: I'm in a Consternation, I never saw such a Hurricane before.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ant.
SP.P: Now Neighbour, what wou'd you give for such a Wife as Cocky?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Dr.
SP.P: Does he Insult, but I'll bear it, I may see his Wife lead him the same Dance, she's in the same Gang, and that's some hopes.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dr.
SP.P: Do but hear me, I'll Appeal to all this Company—

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Dr.
SP.P: Why thou art the very Whore of Babylon, let me reach thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dr.
SP.P: No poor innocent Woman was ever Persecuted thus.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: A fair hace and if I lose my Game I'll Renounce Fornication.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Dra.
SP.P: Lady I shou'd ask your Pardon for this Disturbance, I believe it was against your will, or Mrs. Lucy's either that my Wife was here, but I'll take another opportunity.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Gay.
SP.P: What does the Wretch mean, was there ever so vexatious an Accident?

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: There's my Lady Bellmont below and a Young Lady with her, Come to wait on your Ladyship.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Gay.
SP.P: Cease that Ravens Croak, sure all the World conspire to tor∣ture me, how came she to neglect her Country Huswifry and Visit the Town, which used to be her Aversion, go wait on them up. Lucy, Com∣pose Your Face, don't look with that sorrowful Countenance, as if thou wast going to be Marry'd Dear Sir Anthony let us be merry, let us laugh.

SP.SPEAKER: Dan.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Gay.
SP.P: Ah, sure You imagine them still upon the Road, ten Miles off, I'll ingage▪they'd have heard▪ You, Lord I am overcome with the Flatus—
Dear, Dear Sister this is an unexpected Blessing.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Bell.
SP.P: And Undesir'd by me, the Town and I are no great Friends.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ant.
SP.P: By'r Lady I am glad to see You Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Bell.
SP.P: I thank You, but I'm afraid You want some Money of me for my profuse Son, his Steward tells me, he has had large Sums of You.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ant.
SP.P: VVell well, I have Security in my hands, and by'r Lady he seems to be a hopeful Gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Gay.
SP.P: A pretty Lady with her, an 'twou'd make an agreeable Fi∣gure in my Circle. Madam I hope You have no Quarrel to the Town?

SP.SPEAKER: Angel.
SP.P: We are young Acquaintance yet, and in that State 'tis not na∣tural to be Fond.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Gay.
SP.P: You are so Charming I shall fall in Love with You.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Lov.
SP.P: And I shall grow Jealous.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: VVe must admit this Lady into our Society.

SP.SPEAKER: Angel.
SP.P: Pray what Society?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Gay.
SP.P: The Beaux Esprits, they meet at my Toylet, where there's old striving for Approbation, 'tis that which stamps the Wittling, a Man of Parts Polite, &c. the Sonnetier a Poet, and the dull Insensible, a Man of Intrigue, and Affair, no well bred Lady will admit a Lover but she in∣quires, Is he frequent at my Lady Gaylove's? Does his Coach wait there from Ten to One? I give them the Cadence, the Art of Speaking, the Refin'd Notions.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Bell▪
SP.P: Dear Sister spare your refin'd Notions at this time, I came to see You and your Children, and to talk of a Son of mine, who is so Polite to Visit here.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Gay.
SP.P: Fy, fy, is any thing a greater Indecency, than to talk of one's Children? How can You raise such Odd, Out of the Way, Discourse?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Bell.
SP.P: Now I am Convinc'd the Report was true, we heard in the Country, that You conceal your Children as You do your Wrinkles, and for the same reason You'll pardon my Freedom, for I have resolv'd to see them.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Gay.
SP.P: Devil on her, I shall go Mad. Lucy, call them, [Exit. Lucy.] there's no putting my Sister off, they are a Couple of ∣fashioned Things, for really I find a Woman of my general Acquaintance has too many Affairs upon her hands to throw away any time upon Chil∣dren.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Squire Gaylove and Marina, both aukardly Dress'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Sq.
SP.P: What can we be sent for before all these? Faggs, I'm a∣sham'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Gay.
SP.P: Come Mass and Miss, make the best of your Honours, this is your Aunt.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: Mass and Miss, does she call them! The Fellow looks old enough to beget Sons and Daughters.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Bell.
SP.P: Cozens, You are infinitely grown since I saw you last.

SP.SPEAKER: Sq.
SP.P: I don't Remember I ever saw you before. Is this my Aunt, Mother?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Gay.
SP.P: Mother! Prithee, Child, learn to say Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Sq.
SP.P: Well, Madam then.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Bell.
SP.P: Come hither Marina, You are very Fair.

SP.SPEAKER: Mare.
SP.P: Alas, I am so unpolished, I want Assurance to appear in any Company.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Bell.
SP.P: Prettily answer'd. Sister, You are Cultivating other Beautys and Neglect your Daughter, who is as Lovely, as tis possible Nature can produce.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Gay.
SP.P: A Chit indeed, Sister, for Your sake, I've strangely broke my Rules, they never appear where I am, for tho' they are shot up so, I as∣sure You, the Eldest is not Fifteen, and I was barely that, when I had him.

SP.SPEAKER: Angel.
SP.P: On my Word, he is well grown.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ant.
SP.P: Fine Children, truly, Master is just like his Father, his Nose and Eyes Exactly.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Lov.
SP.P: Miss is the Picture of Lady Gaylove, her Charming Air and Easie Shape.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Gay.
SP.P: Nay, I have been told, that she might Visit some Relations, and pass for my Self.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Bell.
SP.P: That must be where You han't Visited these Twenty Years, Sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: You'll Mortifie her till she turns us out of Doors.

SP.SPEAKER: Dan.
SP.P: Prithee, Master, what Sport do You love, Marbles, or a Top?

SP.SPEAKER: Sq.
SP.P: May hap, Neither.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Dandle will make the Young Squire Angry.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Gay.
SP.P: What Violence do I suffer, oh Insupportable!

SP.SPEAKER: Dan.
SP.P: How do You imploy Your self then, Learning your Lesson, and Saying Your Catechise?

SP.SPEAKER: Sq.
SP.P: Don't make a Game at me, don't, for all your Fine Cloaths, I may hap to give You a Fall, and that wou'd Vex You.

DIV3.STAGE: Dandle Sets his Neckcloath, Squire Gaylove hits him a Slap o' th' Face; Dandle draws his Sword; the Women Shrick; Squire beats Dandle off the Stage. All Run out but Lady Bellmont and Angelica.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Bell.
SP.P: I have no Apprehension of any Danger, but without Cere∣mony, let us be gon.

LG.L: With all my Heart,
And if each Place is fraught with Fools, like this,
To Cure Your Spleen, You cannot go amiss.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE, the PARK.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Bell.
SP.P: SPeak Sincerely, my Dear Angelica, did'st thou ever see any thing so Fantastick as my Sister Gaylove and her Companions; is it not worse than Bedlam, for those poor Creatures can't help it, and she can, Yet this is it my Mad Son delights in: Curse on his Travails, I cou d almost Curse my self, that neglected every other Thought for his Advantage; his Education was my only Care, and he is Ruin'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Angel.
SP.P: Not quite, I hope, Madam; You know I have an Obligation to wish him other ways, and if You please to give me leave, will try to Re∣claim him. He says, I hear, no Woman ever Conquer'd or Out-Witted him; Now I fancy I have as many Crotchets in my Head as he, and I am sure I have more Money, and so have most likelyhood not to fail in my Design.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Bell.
SP.P: Go on, and Heaven Prosper thee. Here comes Valentine, his only Sober Friend.

DIV3.P: Well Valentine, What say's the Reprobate?

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: Faith, Madam, he wants Recruits, each coming Hour brings new Debauches and new Expence.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Bell.
SP.P: Wou'd I cou'd forget him, equally forget the Labour of his Birth and Pleasure, to behold the lovely Boy, Born when his Father was in height of Greatness and of Fondness, Ambassadour in Spain: VVou'd the Remembrance were lost, or he had liv'd to have taught him bet∣ter.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: Believe me, Madam, the Noble Seeds of Honour are mingled with the Fire of Ungovern'd Youth, and will in time Surmount.

SP.SPEAKER: Angel.
SP.P: Hear ye that, Madam, were he a Fool with this Wildness, I shou'd detest him, but a Witty Man some time or other sees his own Faults. A Fool let's all the World see 'em, but never will himself.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: Young Bellmont hates the Common Road, Swears to leave the Estate just as he found it wou'd be, as if he never had been Born.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Bell.
SP.P: Dear Valentine, how stand You in his good Grace?

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: He say's, (in his soberest Minutes) he is my Friend; and I be∣lieve, 'mongst all his Faults, he hates a Lye.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Bell.
SP.P: I know You his, and therefore beg ye to assist this Lady, who has promis'd, from her own goodness chiefly, and a Tye which the Un∣grateful Man seems to forget, to aim at his Amendment: He's not In∣sensible, if he were, such Beauty must prevail.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: Fair Angelica knows I am hers; but first, pray help me in a De∣sign I have on Foot.

SP.SPEAKER: Angel.
SP.P: With all our Hearts: VVhat is't?

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: I have set an Engine at work, to Steal my Lady Gaylove's two large Children.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Bell.
SP.P: Steal her Children!

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: Yes. The Nurse has them often, for a Week, or so, at her dis∣posing; and being a weary of my Lady's Unmindful Usage, brings them to me. I know the Boy of Age to chuse a Guardian, and the Maid is In∣nocent and Pretty: I hope to better them, and make my own Fortunes.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Bell.
SP.P: They can't be worse; Your Designs, I know, are good, and my House, if You please, shall be the Refuge for Marina.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: That was what I wish'd, but wanted boldness to ask; ha, here they are.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Nurse, Squire Gaylove and Marina.

SP.SPEAKER: Sq. Gay.
SP.P: What, Nurse, are we going to your Little House at Chelsey agen, hey?

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: No, Master Gaylove, you are coming to me; and my Lady Bellmont will prove a kinder Mother than her own, to Fair Marina.

SP.SPEAKER: Mari.
SP.P: I must be Instructed, e'er I can pay my Thanks, as I ought, for being deliver'd from the Prison of a Nursery.

SP.SPEAKER: Squ.
SP.P: Ah hey, Nurse, What, this is the Performance of the fine Story you told me last Night, of new Cloaths, a new Guardian; and is it true, Faggs, I thought you had Ly'd, Nurse, Faggs, I did!

SP.SPEAKER: Nurse.
SP.P: You'll find it all true, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Squ.
SP.P: And Nunck, for I suppose you are some kin to me, Faggs, else you wou'd not love me so, shall I have a Sword, and Fight that Boy, lesser than I, that made me as Mad as a Dog, Faggs, he did, Nunck, shall I have a Sword?

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: You shall go to my Lodgings, and have every thing becomes a Gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Squ.
SP.P: La you there now; when wou'd my Mother say so!

SP.SPEAKER: Angel.
SP.P: Oh Education! 'tis to thee we owe the little Light, the All we can discern below; these help't by thee, might have been fine Things. Madam, wou'd You change your Witty Wild Son, for one like this?

SP.SPEAKER: La. Bell.
SP.P: Folly is better than Wickedness.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: Nurse, there▪s Money for you; pray set the Squire down at my Lodgings, where every thing is prepar'd to Equip him.

SP.SPEAKER: Nurse.
SP.P: Yes, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Squ.
SP.P: Come away, Nurse, I long for a Sword, Faggs, I do; 'b'ye Sister, come Nurse, Farewel Mamma, Faggs, I care not, I shall not cry to such—Faggs, come along Nurse, for a Sword, Midhap I mid along'd Nurse.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Bell.
SP.P: Come, Fair Neice, you are not afraid to trust your self with me?

SP.SPEAKER: Mare.
SP.P: No, Madam, it's what I chuse and wish.

DIV3.STAGE: Sir James Crosses the Stage with Mrs. Draul.

SP.SPEAKER: Angel.
SP.P: Ha, my Libertine, I beg you'd leave me with my Woman, and Pray for my Success.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: We do, heartily.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Bell.
SP.P: Farewel, my brave, best Girl.

SP.SPEAKER: Angel.
SP.P: Hariot, be sure you do it well, you have my full Instructions.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: I warrant You, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Angel.
SP.P: I'll to the next Passage, and take a Chair. The Twisted Posts, remember.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Yes, Madam, 'twas lucky to find him here.

SP.SPEAKER: Angel.
SP.P: That was all one, he must have been found; mind You your Bu∣siness.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Fear not, I wou'd do any thing to serve you.

SP.SPEAKER: Angel.
SP.P: I know thee Faithful, and wish the Fortunate. Make hast.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: They Cross agen, I'll observe a little—

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Sir James and Mrs. Draul.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Come, Madam, be pacify'd; a Lady of Spirit, Beauty and Youth, as you are, wou'd but laugh at such a Disgrace.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dr.
SP.P: Aye, Sir James, if one had deserv'd it; but to be expos'd for nothing, goes to my Heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: The only way to ease your heart, is to deserve it. I vow to Gad, Madam, it sticks upon a pretty Woman's Conscience, when a Cross Husband is Jealous without Cause, she suffers all the Torment without the Pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dr.
SP.P: Is't possible?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Most true: What d'ye think I dandle after▪ye for, but to Convince ye of this Doctrine!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dr.
SP.P: Fy, fy, Sir James.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Fy, fy, Sir James, with that Air, I shall lose my Man, if I don't make hast. (comes forward.) Sir, Sir,

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: What say'st thou, Child?

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: There is a Lady—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Whist, a Message from my Mother: Dear Madam, walk on a little way.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dr.
SP.P: No matter where, for I am in a Mortified Condition. (goes on▪)

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: What Lady, my Dear, Dear Embassadress of Love, I read it in thy Eyes; what Lady, Chicken?

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Stark mad for a New Woman—Oh, she is Young and Gay as April Flowers, as Beautiful as Rosie Mornings in the pleasing Month of May.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: All upon Similies, I Faith, and lives in Paradise; purling Streams are at her Feet, and Dewy Streets shed all their Odours on her. Come come, quick, the Sign, the Street, the Name, Quick, Quick.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: But you are Ingag▪d.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: You see I am; therefore swear, swear, ye little Gypsie, by some dreadful Oath, fix some horrid Imprecation, that she's handsomer than this Woman, or from the Disappointment expect no Mercy.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: May the Curse of Woman-kind be mine; may I dye an Old Maid without the Reputation of Vertue; may I always stay two hours waiting in every Assignation, and then be Disappointed; may I lose my Teeth, my Hair, my Eyes—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Hold, hold, enough, enough, if what?

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: If my Lady does not as much exceed that Thing, as a French Air does a Dutch, or an English Beauty an Ethiopian.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: I am satisfy'd: How shall I go to her, my little Angel?

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: In a Whirlwind, follow me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: And most luckily here comes Company; I can have my Dis∣consolate Damsel in.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Sir Anthony, Careless, and Dandle.
DIV3.P: Madam, my Mother sends, upon her Blessing, I shou'd come: I beg your Pardon, and will commit ye to my Friend Careless, and your Neigh∣bour, Sir Anthony.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dr.
SP.P: With all my heart, for I wou'd tell Sir Anthony my Story.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Now my little Pegasus, my pretty Nimble-Chops, away, away.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Quick then, if you follow me.

SP.SPEAKER: Dan.
SP.P: Aye Sir, the Elements Met, Met, Sir; Fire, Air, Water, Earth and Fire, and Six more, Sir, they made a terrible Rumble.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Where was this, Dandle?

SP.SPEAKER: Dan.
SP.P: In Jamaica. Gad if you had seen 'em helter skelter, you'd never have forgot it: Down come a Torrent, up starts a Whale, away flys a Mountain, shudder shudder comes a Rock in its Place; thus it is, as it were topsy turvy, Sir; d'ye mind me, Sir Anthony?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Aut.
SP.P: Yes, Yes; but I wonder where Cocky is, she said this Walk, I am sure she did?

SP.SPEAKER: Dan.
SP.P: Then the Great Mogul's Niece, Lord, how fond she was of me, nd his Daughter In-Law, Sir Anthony—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ant.
SP.P: May be so, Sir, I did not know her.

SP.SPEAKER: Dan.
SP.P: Not know her, Sir, she was—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ant.
SP.P: Like enough.—
What, I must speak to Mrs. Draul. Neighbour, why your Husband's a Whimsical Man: hey, Neighbour?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dr.
SP.P: Hye, if you knew my Innocency, I that have made Candles▪ I that have been a Slave to his Infirmities upon all occasions, to be left at last to the Inhumane World▪ only for going with Mrs. Tyewell; ah, ah, Sir Anthony, 'twas not so of Old, the City was in better Discipline.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ant.
SP.P: 'Twas so, 'twas so, Mrs. Draul; (I wonder where Cocky is) but Mrs▪ Draul, did that same Mr. Tyewell propose any thing to ye, hea?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dr.
SP.P: No, no, Sir Anthony, 'twas Mrs. Tyewell, nothing neither in Word nor Deed: Captain Careless was by, Sir; speak Sir, was there any Signs of harm?

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: None, none in the VVorld; the Frollick was a very pretty Frol∣lick.

SP.SPEAKER: Dan.
SP.P: A very pretty Frollick, Lady Loveman has done as much a Thou∣sand times.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ant.
SP.P: How, my Cocky, no Mrs. Draul, my Cocky is too Nice; the Fellows may Talk, but Cocky goes no farther.

SP.SPEAKER: Dan.
SP.P: Nay, she'll Smile, and Ogle, and Wink, to my knowledge; and these are shrew'd Signs, Sir Anthony.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Dr.
SP.P: What Signs, ye Coxcomb; 'tis such Pick-Thanks as you, turn honest Men's Brains, so 'tis.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ant.
SP.P: True, Mrs. Draul; there's ne'er a Man in England can say black is Cocky's Eye, tho' she has the finest Eyes in the whole World, such a Sparkle, such a Turn, oh my Cocky's Eyes, (but I wonder where she is) such Eyes, Mr. Careless—

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Brilliants, upon Honour, Sir Anthony.

SP.SPEAKER: Dan.
SP.P: Brilliants, ah, if you had seen Prester John's Daughter, there were Eyes, the rest of the World's are all like Dead Whiteings Compar'd to 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ant.
SP.P: 'Tis false, Mr. Dandle; there's ne'er a John's Daughter in Town or Country, to Compare with Cocky's.

SP.SPEAKER: Dan.
SP.P: How Sir, Contradict the known Verdit of my Travails, you are a Poltron.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ant.
SP.P: You are a Lyar by Authority, take that for your Poltreon, (Strikes him, and Struts about.) I'll dye in Defence of Cocky's Eyes.

SP.SPEAKER: Dan.
SP.P: And I in the Glory of Maintaining the Princess of Zamaracandas, let me come at him.

SP.SPEAKER: Care.
SP.P: Civil Wars will ensue, d'ye Consider where you are, in the Park!

SP.SPEAKER: Dan.
SP.P: 'Tis well, I shall take a time—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ant.
SP.P: So shall I, to Cudgel ye: Cocky's Eyes abus'd. Ha, who's yonder, is not that Cocky, let's make hast!

SP.SPEAKER: Dan.
SP.P: I'll go with you, to prove to ye—

SP.SPEAKER: Slr Ant.
SP.P: What?

SP.SPEAKER: Dan.
SP.P: That You are a Fool.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ant.
SP.P: Thou art all over Impudence, but I'll hasten to see if that bean't Cocky, come Neighbour Draul.

SP.SPEAKER: Care.
SP.P: How foolishly i appearance, do I spend my time, but 'tis not without Design, to be richly paid for't.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE, Lady Gaylove▪s.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Lady Gaylove, Lady Loveman, and Lucy.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: Lucy, get the little Snug Tea-Table ready, bid the Footman at the Fore-Door say I am not at Home, order Trusty Sam. at the Back-Door to let in my Lord Court all.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: Yes Madam; wou'd your Ladyship have none else but Lord Court all Admitted?

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: No, Fool.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: I understand ye, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Lov.
SP.P: Lord, how I tremble to have a Correspondence carry such a Face of an Intrigue; indeed he▪ a Man of Quality, and that weighs much with a Citizens Wife; but then my Vertue, Lady Gaylove, and his noisy Thing, his Spouse, a Creature infinitely Jealous, how wou'd my Re∣putation suffer, were our Innocent Conversation discover'd!

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: Your Reputation, Madam; there's no Woman in the whole Town stands upon her Reputation more than my self; but a little Chatt, and a great deal of Love, are the prettyest Things in this World: Pri∣thee tell me, how and how, prithee do, what Progress he has made?

SP.SPEAKER: La. Lov.
SP.P: None at all, I assure ye, Madam; he dares not own his Flame.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: But You can guess at it, hey, Child?

SP.SPEAKER: La. Lov.
SP.P: I must confess, he buzes in my Ears in the Box, when I miss a Fore-Row and am Condemn'd to a Fourth.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: Good, Good!

SP.SPEAKER: La. Lov.
SP.P: Nay, he has sent me several Letters, but I always return'd them, never broke the Seals of one, and was very Angry with my Woman.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: Ah, I us'd to be very Angry with my Woman too, but cou'd never forbear Opening the Letters.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Lov.
SP.P: Hush, I hear him coming, am I in order?

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: A small Recruit, and your Force will be Invincible.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Lov.
SP.P: How?

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: Paint, Paint agen, 'tis the first thing I do in a Morning, yet ever secure a hidden Reserve for all day, as Nature's Paint fades in few Years, so that in few Hours; did you perceive me then?

SP.SPEAKER: La. Lov.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: That Moment I gave my Cheeks and Lips a Tincture; my iankerchief, my Sleeve, my Bosom, all are furnish'd. [Shows her.] I lean't in Franc, they do it there perpetually.

SP.SPEAKER: Ld. Cour.
SP.P: My Lady Gaylove, the Soul of Wit and Gallantry!

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: My Lord Courtall, the Spirit of Conversation, Delight of the Lady's, and Emulation of the Beaux; but what say you to this Goddess of Beauty?

SP.SPEAKER: Ld. Court.
SP.P: There Admiration and Pleasure strikes me Dumb!

SP.SPEAKER: La. Lov.
SP.P: You are very Polite, my Lord, nor am I unmindful of your Merit; I assure ye this is the first time I e'er Consented to Drink Tea in a Corner.

SP.SPEAKER: Ld. Court.
SP.P: Ah Madam, I hope you'll relish the Sweetness on't; the prettyest Things in the World are done in a Corner.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha, but in no Corner of mine I protest, my Lord; pray do not imagine me ever guilty of an Indecorum.

SP.SPEAKER: Ld. Court.
SP.P: Oh fie, Madam, I know you better!

SP.SPEAKER: La. Lov.
SP.P: Come let us go to the Table then, we must be speedy, I'm sure when my Buddy Misses me in the Park, he'll come directly to my Lady Gaylove's.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: Fear not, Careless and Dandle have my Orders to Amuse him. Use no Constraint, my Lord; I'm afraid he'll not make his Address before me, and then my Pleasure's lost.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Lov.
SP.P: My Lord, will You Sit

SP.SPEAKER: Ld. Court.
SP.P: By You? With all my heart, thou fairest Blossom productive Nature ever Form'd.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Lov.
SP.P: Now this is what you have said all over already; I must con∣fess I shou'd abhor Love from a Married Man—

SP.SPEAKER: Ld. Court.
SP.P: Ah Madam—

SP.SPEAKER: La. Lov.
SP.P: In any but my Lord Courtall.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: VVell Redeem'd, upon my Honour, she put him in a Cold Sweat.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Lov.
SP.P: Nor can I forbear ever being in Apprehension of your Wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Ld. Court.
SP.P: No more, I beseech ye Madam, if I but hear her Nam'd, I'm Sick that Day.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: Polite, I profess; is your Tea good, my Dear?

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: Oh my Lady Courtall's below, say's You are at Home, and she will see ye; she follows me, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Lov.
SP.P: Betray'd, Undone!

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: You Undone! What will become of me, all my Decorum's broke!

SP.SPEAKER: Ld. Court.
SP.P: I'll be gon.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Gay.
SP.P: Oh you meet her there, these Upper Apartments have but one Pair of Stairs; I hear her coming up; into the Closet, and sit close, still, I mean, or I'm ruin'd; in, in, I say.

DIV3.STAGE: Locks them in. Lord Courtall leaves his Hat upon a Chair.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Court.
SP.P: I hope my Lady Gaylove will pardon this Freedom, but I have such earnest business—ha, you seem surpriz'd, Madam!

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: To be caught in such Disorder, by a Person of your Lady∣ships Quality, puts me in great Confusion; Lucy, set away the Things quickly.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Court.
SP.P: I see the Hat, and want no other Proof; I know the Diamond-Buckle. 'Tis very well, Madam, and I'll tell ye my De∣sign and Business; my Lord is going to take the House just opposite to yours, and I have a mind to see if this is fitted like it, and to ask your Opinion, I know my Lord admires your Judgment.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: Safety's the Word, and the Danger's over. With all my heart, Dear Madam; in the first Apartments I think there's some∣thing Curious, Conveniencys which perhaps your Ladyship may not have observ'd.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Court.
SP.P: I fancy so there is here. Lady Gaylove, pray let me look on this first, is this View into the Park, Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: Yes, Madam. (Aside) I begin to be in a Cold Sweat agen.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Court.
SP.P: And this Closet, is it pretty?

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: I hope it will, but 'tis not yet Furnish'd.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Court.
SP.P: I pray let's see it.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: I, I, I broke the Key in it this Morning. So now 'twill out.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Court.
SP.P: The Deceit's too plain, and thus I expose ye all.
SP.STAGE: (Flys against it, and beats it open)
SP.P: So Devil thon art my prey.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: Oh, in my House, my Decorms, my Decorums!

SP.SPEAKER: La. Lov.
SP.P: Some help, she'll tear me to pieces!

SP.SPEAKER: Ld. Court.
SP.P: Cease for Woman-hood, for shame!

SP.SPEAKER: La. Court.
SP.P: Let me come at her, let me come at her!

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: Save me save me!

SP.SPEAKER: Ld. Court.
SP.P: Fear not, I'll calm this mighty Fury; know Ladies, this is not my Wife, one who in my Doting Fondness, I gave the priviledge to be call'd so, and thus she uses it.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Court.
SP.P: Villain, 'tis false.

SP.SPEAKER: Ld. Court.
SP.P: Woman, 'tis true; and be you Silent for ever, and gone, or all the World shall know it.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Cot.
SP.P: Will you go with me then?

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Court.
SP.P: Yes, to rid the House of such a Fury. A Wife,—like Vir∣tue, is to bear; and those Nobly Born, scorn Extravagance, like this.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: Not Married, Madam, I must beg of you to be gon, a Wo∣man of your Character sullys my Apartments, polutes my Circle, I pro∣fess!

SP.SPEAKER: Ld. Court.
SP.P: That's too much, Lady Gaylove; but we'll be gon, another time I shall take, to ask your Pardon for this Rudeness.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Court.
SP.P: Oh! I shall burst with inward Rage, but he has stop'd my Mouth.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: How does my Dearest? Come, chear up, I warrant her Tongue's ruled, and we shall hear no more of this.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Lov.
SP.P: Oh, I am frighted to Death! All my Head-Cloaths are off. Well, I solemnly swear, never to have an Intrigue agen, with a Man that has but the least Shaddow of an Ingagement, that any other Woman can lay the least Claim too.
Why where's Cocky, I can't find Cocky; why nown Cocky?

SP.SPEAKER: La. Lov.
SP.P: Oh Heavens! My Husband: Now my Misery's Compleat.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: Lucy, is the Devil in ye, to let this Fool come up without Notice!

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: Madam, I am▪hared out of my Wits.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ant.
SP.P: Hey, Cocky a top o' th' House! I have left Careless and Neigh∣bour Draul below, Impertinence wou'd follow. What's the matter, Cocky?

SP.SPEAKER: La. Lov.
SP.P: Oh, oh, oh.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: Oh, I find it! Alas, she has been in Fitts this hour, and frighted me out of my Sences▪

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ant.
SP.P: Cocky in a Fitt! Ah, Undone, Undone! Run for some Cold Water; for Heavens sake, speak to me, Cocky, speak to thy nown Tony; ah, ah, help, Mr. Dandle!

SP.SPEAKER: Dan.
SP.P: Aye, aye; let me come.
SP.STAGE: (runs, and tumbles over the Tea Table.)

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: A Devil; the Dog has thrown down my Tea Table!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ant.
SP.P: No matter▪ Lady Gaylove, I'll give thee another, do but help my Dear Cocky: Ah, she revives a little, oh, dear Cocky!

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: How is it now, Madam? Poor Lucy and I have held her thus this hour, till her Cloaths are all pull'd off almost.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy,
SP.P: Aye, my Arms ake, and my Heart akes. 'Twas a sad Sight.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ant.
SP.P: Ah poor Cocky; send for a Doctor, send for a Doctor, some of you; good People send for a Doctor!

SP.SPEAKER: La. Lov.
SP.P: I▪m a little better now, my Dear.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir. Ant.
SP.P: What, thy nown Dear, do'st thou speak agen, my Jewel!

SP.SPEAKER: Dan.
SP.P: Why, what the Devil's the meaning of all this! I believe some body has been pulling her Head-Cloaths off.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: Out of the Room, ye pittyless Monster, ye Scaudalous Cur.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ant.
SP.P: Get ye gon, ye Prophane Son of the Great Mogul.

SP.SPEAKER: Dan.
SP.P: No matter for that; here's something thou do'st not understand, Prigg.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: Mind him not. Shall we remove to larger Rooms, my Dear, for more Air?

SP.SPEAKER: La. Lov.
SP.P: With all my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ant.
SP.P: Pray, your hands; lean upon me, Cocky. Unfortunate Man, that I shou'd live to see my Cocky sick; lean upon me.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Lov.
SP.P: Softly, my Love.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ant.
SP.P: Ay, ay, my Dear.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.STAGE: [Claps her upon the Shoulder, and crys]
SP.P: Well done Cocky, well done Cocky.

SP.SPEAKER: Angel.
SP.P: Why beats my Heart with such unusual Motion! Why do I sigh and blush, and fear the Tryal! Success attends on Virtue: I love this Wanderer; tis all I wish, to make him mine for ever. And hear me, ye Powers that favour Goodness; touch his wild Soul with the kind Shaft of Love, and Crown my Just, my Virgin VVishes. I hear him coming, and will retire to raise his Expectation.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Well, we have drove like the Devil; and where are we now?

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Don't you see, in a handsom Apartment: Where wou'd you be?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: But the Lady, Child,

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Is coming; I gave the Signal, and I know she'll be here in a Twinkling.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: But is she Young, the very Blew upon the Plumb; Fair as Opening Flowers, and all those Damn'd fine Things thou say'dst at first, Child, ha?

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Nay, your own Eyes must be Judge; I'll not Fore-stall.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: The Devil! Support me, or I Faint!

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Shaw, Shaw, this is her Governante.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Oh, I Recover agen!

SP.SPEAKER: Gover.
SP.P: My Lady; Sir, will VVai upon you as soon as ever she has ad∣sted an Unruly Curl behind.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: I long, with Impatience, to kiss her Fair Hands. Now, must I pretend to know her, to this Antiquated Gentlewoman? Hark ye, you little Air and Fire; your Lady sends this Duena, I suppose, as Ben. Johnson prepar'd his Witches, to set his Beauty's off at Court-Masks.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: That, I believe, is her Design.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: But, I hope, when she appears, you Vanish?

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Most Dutifully.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Ha, a Blushing Beauty, beyond Example, Fair!

SP.SPEAKER: Angel.
SP.P: You'r Welcome, Sir, are you not surpriz'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: At such a Miracle, it is impossible to be otherwise.

SP.SPEAKER: Angel.
SP.P: I mean, at the Oddness of your Coming. Set Chairs, Harriot.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: And Retire.

SP.SPEAKER: Angel.
SP.P: I have often seen you, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: In love with my proper Person, that's Certain.

SP.SPEAKER: Angel.
SP.P: And being free, and at my own dispose, wou'd view your Mind, and if that answers, I may pronounce ye perfect. Pray tell me first, your Notion of Love?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Faith, Madam, I'll be plain with ye: None of your Sex can lay Falshood to my Charge, for I give 'em fair VVarning, and tell 'em be∣fore-hand, what they must trust to: I may swear, as the rest do, Custom has tagged it to Love-Speeches; but I never wish 'em to Credit my Oaths, and if they'll deceive themselves, who can help it?

SP.SPEAKER: Angel.
SP.P: I find now a days, Love and Religion are Modell'd by every Profession. Pray what kind of Passion do you Propose?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: That which Nature first Inspir'd, and still Continues among the Undegenerate part of the Creation: The happy Animals know no Confinement, they meet and love, then part and Range, neither Upbraid∣ing when they meet agen; Falshood and Jealousie ne'er break their Peace.

SP.SPEAKER: Angel.
SP.P: Then you Imitate the Brutes?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Not so, but I lose no Advantage they can boast; Reason, the vast distinction of our Species, refines the Bliss, and equals us to Jove; and Conversation gives a grateful Relish, keeping the soft Impression still in Memory. Come, let's retire, and tast the Sweets of Love the best, most perfect, pleasing way?

SP.SPEAKER: Agel.
SP.P: Shou'd I consent, wou'd you not hate me for it; were I Con∣vinc▪d of that—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Try me, thou softest, dearest of thy Sex, if thou repent'st, my Life shall be thy Sacrifice.

SP.SPEAKER: Angel.
SP.P: Then▪ I confess a Temper free as yours; so apt to Love, and so disdaining Bondage, without Controul we'll Revel all the Night, and in the Morning, rise without distrust, each in the dear pursuit of newer Conquest.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: O Extasie! Is there Beauty and such Wildness joyn'd? A Soul so like my own! I must Embrace thee as my dearest Treasure, the only Jewel I have ever found.

SP.SPEAKER: Angel.
SP.P: Hold, hold, Sir; e'er our Alliance grows stricter, pray let me know your Name, for I confess my self an absolute stranger.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: All the better, Child, yet to be upon the square, Madam, you shou'd begin no Curiosity, but for fear of losing such a Blessing, makes me desire it.

SP.SPEAKER: Angel.
SP.P: I readily Comply. Mine is Dona Angliana Hispaniola Amora.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: A Devilish long Spanish Name, but a Charming English Face; for the Name, no matter. Faith, Madam, Mine's somewhat shorter, which I fear, you may dislike: However, to help it out, Thanks to my Forefathers Parents, ▪t'has a Knight-Hood tack'd to it, and I am call'd, Sir James Bellmont.

SP.SPEAKER: Angel.
SP.P: Shricks out help, help, and falls in a Sound.

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: What have you done, base Man?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Faith, Child, kill d her with my Name; tho', I'll be Judg'd by the whole World, if hers did not seem to have most danger in the Sound.

SP.SPEAKER: Gover.
SP.P: What's the Matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Angel.
SP.P: Flys to Embrace him.
Stand off, this is Sir James Bellmont, Governess.

SP.SPEAKER: Gover.
SP.P: Ah, ah; Sir James Bellmont!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Ye Immortal Gods, who the Devil am I▪ Hers was a sweet Embrace! The Old Fool Drevils.

SP.SPEAKER: Angel.
SP.P: Yet lead me from him, he is too Lovely, and our Fate denys!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: For Heavens sake, Madam, explain your self; for I am a Dog if I can Understand ye!

SP.SPEAKER: Angel.
SP.P: Such was your Father, such his Matchless Grace, when in his Youth, in Spain, he paid his Vows to my Unhappy Mother, Dona Amora, she dyed; but for the Love she bore her first plighted Lord, sent me to England, for my Education, where, till this hour, I never heard of you, my too, too dear Brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Nor I of you, my too, too dear Sister. Prithee, let's forget our Kin, and renew our Love, that's better by half.

SP.SPEAKER: Angel.
SP.P: What! horrid Incest! Away, away, lead me from those too pow∣erful Eyes!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Unhappy Dm Sebastian, henceforward, I'll be call'd. Am I Inchanted, what can this mean! But hold, I'll raise some of the House, and be Conducted to my Dear Sister, tho' 'tis but Charitable to Comfort her in her Distress. Here, where are you all, who lives in this House?

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Did you call, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Yes, Sir, I did call. Pray show me the way to Dona Angliana Hispaniola Amora's Chamber. Does not a Spanish Lady Lodge here?

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Sir, here came some Ladies about two hours ago, and gave a Guinea Earnest for the Lodgings; but they are just gon laughing away, in a Hackney-Coach that waited, and said, they believ'd they shou'd come no more.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P:
Trick'd, for nothing, Trick'd. Call me another Coach: If not my Sister, then, Fair Sorceress, beware—
I cannot Storm, if I Consult my Heart:
The Inchanter Claims above a Sister's Part.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT III.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: WHAT kind Intelligence do'st thou bring? What New Intrigue is Forming? For Love and Pleasure glows in thy Cheeks, and sparkles in thy Eyes. See, here's a Letter from Lady Courtall; all are kind, but Espaniola.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Wou'd I had been Born to thy happy Fortune; those Amorous Eyes Win every Heart they aim at. Here's a Note slipt into my hand, by pretty Lady Loveman; Directed to Sir James Bellmont. VVho wou'd not Envy thee!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Dear Creature, let me Kiss it: (Reads) Sir Anthony is gon into the City, and that Mischievous, Interrupting Wretch, Dandle, by my persuasions, is gon with him. I shall be at Lady Gaylove's; where, if you are at leisure, we may Trifle an Hour agreeably.—'Tis well Contriv'd, by Venus; and once it would have fir'd me to the purpose; but now, that Lovely, Spanish, Cruel, Witty Devil, dwells in my Thoughts, and allows but half Inclination.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: That's a Whimsical Story: Can't you guess who the Lady was?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Oh, no: For if I had not kiss'd her hand, and found it Sub∣stance, I should have thought some Goddess had been upon the Ramble, as they used to be of Old, and took me in her way, for the Jests sake.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: No Rapture, good Sir James, but let us fly; you know I must be there to engage Lady Gaylove, or she'll give you no opportunity to make a Private Assignation, and yet stand so upon her Decorums, you must not speak a Word aloud.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: I'll go with thee presently; but first let me see my Old Fellow out of the Country; I expect him every Moment; Money must be had; Business of any other kind, might wait.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Ay, Money must be had: Well, I'll loyter at Mrs. Tyewell's, till you Call for me.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Lady Bellmont and Valentine, to Sir James.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Ha, my Mother! The only Female, who, if I durst, I wou'd forbid my Lodgings. Madam, you are Welcome; this is indeed a Fa∣vour: But can you tell me, are the VVritings Coming?

SP.SPEAKER: La. Bell.
SP.P: I find, my Son, you are the same you was; a lavish Repro∣bate, Thoughtless of Time to come;—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: I apprehend your Admonition is design'd long, but i'll spare you the Trouble, for by the Sympathy of Nature, I can guess all you wou'd say, and much Talking is a prejudice to the Lungs.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Bell.
SP.P: Thou barefac'd Libertine!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: So much the more Honourable; I hate the sneaking Rogues that dare not own their Principles; they love Variety as well as I, and Drink and Fornicate in Corners, till they are a Scandal to the Vices they Profess: I wear no Cloak.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Bell.
SP.P: Degenerate Boy, thou blemish of thy Family, boast'st thou hy Crimes at this Audacious Rate! Is this the Effect of all my tender Care! For shame, Reform, and save the little Moyety thy Vices yet have left: If thou goest on but ne'er so little longer, foulest Disgrace and endless Beggary waits thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Tis pitty good Advice shou'd thus be lost, but Reformation is a hard Lesson, and I am not Serious enough to Study. I suppose—now you know my Sentiments, we may change the Discourse.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Bell.
SP.P: Just Heaven, what have I done, how have I Sinn'd, to Merit so severe Punishment!

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: Sir James, we came hither to Consult calmly, and to make a Pro∣posal, infinitely to your Advantage: Your Mother thinks Matrimony, wou'd take you off from these wild Courses.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Won't a Dose of Opium do as well? For I have been told, by very wise Astrologers, that when ever I Married, I was a Dead-Man.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Bell.
SP.P: The Lady I have Chose, is Nobly Born; and has a Fortune large enough to Retrieve what you have lost, and supply your Future Ex∣travagance.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Is she Young and Beautiful; if so, perhaps I may Consent to Visit her, and persuade her to be mine upon easier Terms?

SP.SPEAKER: La. Bell.
SP.P: She has neither Beauty enough to Tempt, nor Folly to be De∣ceiv'd; she has out-lived the idle Qualms of Love-Sick Girls, and will make a Prudent Wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: That's as much as to say, she is Old and Ugly; my Curiosity's satisfied, Madam▪ since the Lady's your Friend, I wish her well; some Superannuated eau or Unfortunate Gamester may be glad of her; and they understand the Punctilios of good Breeding, and make Civil Hus∣bands.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Bell.
SP.P: I see my Care for thee, is all in vain, and Patience and Af∣fection will be worn out at last. Farewel, Unthinking Man.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: Perhaps you may Reflect when we are gon; there wants but that and you wou'd soon Comply with all your Mother's Wishes.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: So, I am in a fine Condition; instead of saving my Estate, she wou'd persuade me to Mortgage my self; but thanks to Mercury, her Son is a little wiser: What, no Writings yet!

SP.SPEAKER: Hearty.
SP.P: Nea, nea, Master, Cham so loft to give the Writings. Wa's me; I little thaught his Worship's Son, wou'd ha done thus, Murrain, and the Betts, take his French Breeding and he had liv'd at Whom, and Ri over his Vather's Land, he'd scant parted with them thus.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Honest Hearty, hast forgot thy Master?

SP.SPEAKER: Hearty.
SP.P: Methinks I have some Glimps on him, but that Paund of Hair hides his Vace so, troth his own White Locks were main handsomer▪ (Cryes.) yea, I Remember him a meer Urchin.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Give him some Sack, let him drown Sorrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: I suppose you have liv'd long in the Family, you look Antient, Friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Hearty.
SP.P: Spare your Flouts, I was his Vather's Steward, and his Grand∣vather's Steward; but I guess if Young Master keeps thee long, there will be small want of that Office.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Drink thy Sack, Hearty, and mind him not.

SP.SPEAKER: Hearty.
SP.P: Yea, he has Master's good Nature, an he wou'd but be Claim'd. Well, take the Writings, I ha no heart to deny you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Well sed Rural; here, carry them to Sir Anthony's, and bring the Summ we agreed on; take Hearty to the Tavern; now I am qualified for New Pleasures;

Q.L: Or, with full Leisure, to Run o'er the Old:
We cannot want; when VVe've secur'd the Gold.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE Changes to Lady Gaylove's.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Lady Gaylove, and Lady Loveman.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Lov.
SP.P: Come, let Decorums be forgot, I am resolv'd for Love and Mirth.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: Dear Creature, I dare not: Oh Reputation, Reputation! what do'st thou make me suffer!

SP.SPEAKER: La. Lov.
SP.P: What would you give to wish so little, yet venture so far as I?

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: Excuse my Answer, and vary the Subject: Prithee, tell me some News; what Young Wife has forsook her Husband's Vocation, to set up for her self; what old Fellow, weary of Peace and Reputation, has twisted his Neck into the Noose of Matrimony; what Proud Beauty lies sick of the Small Pox; or what Affected Vertue suffers by Lampoon? I have been so busied with Amours, I han't had leisure to enquire of the World these two Days.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Lov.
SP.P: Then you han't heard the Story of my Lord Flash, who, to save Expences, always Intrigues with other Mens Mistresses.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: That Compound of Thrift and Vanity: Prithee, what of him?

SP.SPEAKER: La. Lov.
SP.P: Only being Surpriz'd by the Jealous Keeper, in Bed with Faith∣ful Phillis, he unadvisedly took shelter up the next Room Chimney; was unluckily found, and besides the Disgrace and a few Stripes, has Irreco∣verably lost his Complexion.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha, I'm almost inclin'd to Pitty.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Lov.
SP.P: Then, poor Madam Dotage, lies desperately Sick of Love and Disappointment.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: Well, I'll swear, that Antiquated Figure of Amorous Gallan∣try, has often put me out of Countenance.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Lov.
SP.P: Her Tongue is the Emblem of perpetual Motion; you might as well hope to stop a Lawyer in the midst of his Harangue, as make her hear any thing but her self.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: Her Lovers, high Birth; generous Education, and her Interest at Court, are her Eternal Themes; and she's sure to promise a Man the first Place that falls, tho' she never saw him before.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Lov.
SP.P: Ay, and ingage to Introduce him to his Grace as a particular Friend, when his Valet-de-Chambre is all she knows of the Family: She has ly'd so long, that she deceives her self.

SP.SPEAKER: La▪ Gay.
SP.P: She reported, it cost her a Thousand Pounds last Year, to keep a Gallant, when 'twou'd puzzle her to raise Fifty, if it cou'd Re∣deem her Youth and Fame.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Lov.
SP.P: This is the last News you'll hear of her, forsaken by Sharp, and despised by the Town: She has took it to heart, and resolves, if she recovers, to Reform, even in the View of all the Joys▪ Threescore can give; will renounce Mankind, and Retire.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: Why, then Adieu, formal Gentility, affected Generosity, and barefac'd Lewdness.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Lov.
SP.P: Well, there are but two Things worth our Thoughts, that's Love and Scandal: And now we are out of Breath at the one, what Charming Variety it is to change thus to the other.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Lovely Charmer, this was a kind Contrivance; and you shall own I have a Sence of Gratitude.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Lov.
SP.P: Dear Sir James, be Merciful in your Extrasy, I'm not able to bear this violent Acknowledgment.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Let us not loyter here; 'twere pitty to throw away the few Mi∣nutes Fortune gives us to injoy.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: Now, what can we four do, to Divert our selves?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Let Nature Instruct, she has the readyest Invention on such occasions.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Lov.
SP.P: Let's go to the Play, there we are sure to miss Sir Anthony.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Venus forbid that Design; ▪tis an idle hour indeed, when I Consent to be Entertained with any Body's Intrigues but my own.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: I never go there but when I have the Flatus, and then the Ill Faces and Aukward Dresses generally give me ease.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Come, let us make—Cartc Paic—and go where none can Gaze or Prate to Interrupt the Stolen Sweets of Love.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: I'm almost afraid this is violating Decorums, but I hope amongst Friends my Reputation is safe.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: I hope, Madam, you think better of us than to Fear.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: Mr. Dandle, Sir Anthony; stay and have your Shoes wip'd, do you think my Lady can bear her Rooms should have the Ayre of a Counting-House?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: The Fool's return'd, Curse of Disappointment.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: Oh Heavens, what shall we do, if we are seen together! That Vermin will whim it into Sir Anthony's head, that 'twas by Assigna∣tion!

SP.SPEAKER: La. Lov.
SP.P: That Coxcomb has taught him to Contradict Nature, and be Jealous.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Are there no Back-Stairs, that we may slip down?

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: None, none; good Mr. Careless get under the Couch, Dear Sir James lye you upon it, there, now help me to throw my Night-Gown over him; so, I'll set down on the Couch carelessly, and that will hide all.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Lov.
SP.P: If we can but send the Wretches away without suspition, we may pursue our Frollick.

SP.SPEAKER: Dan.
SP.P: All alone, never a Beaux Esprit; sure, Venus is Retrogade to day; but we are come to your Relief.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: Dandle, if thou hast the least Respect for me, prithee give a Proof of it by thy speedy Absence.

SP.SPEAKER: Dan.
SP.P: Hey, hey, sure your Ladyship has the Flatus!

SP.SPEAKER: La. Lov.
SP.P: Why did nown Dear, say he should not come home all day, and make Cocky go Abroad?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ant.
SP.P: I, I did go, with a Design, as I thought, to do some Busi∣ness; but, but Mr. Dandle can tell best; for I think of nothing but Loving thee. Is not my Lady Gaylove Well?

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: My Head's a little Disorder'd, that's all.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ant.
SP.P: By'r Lady, a very scurvy Pain.

SP.SPEAKER: Dan.
SP.P: A Dram of Ratifia is a present Cure.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Lov.
SP.P: You don't go into the City agen to day, do you, Dear?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ant.
SP.P: No, here Mr. Dandle wou'd bring me back, he fancied You were here, and—

SP.SPEAKER: Dan.
SP.P: Hold, or you Ruin me for ever with Lady Gaylove!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ant.
SP.P: Nay, all shall out.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Lov.
SP.P: I suppose he invented some Story against me; was it not so?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ant.
SP.P: He wou'd buz it in my Ears, that Cocky was false, and had an Appointment here, with some young Fellow, because you hurried us away; but I did not believe him: Yet he wou'd come back, and over∣persuade me; tho' I am glad now, since I found you alone by your selves.

SP.SPEAKER: Dan.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha, only a Devise to come to Lady Gaylov that Mi∣nute; for by Sympathy, I knew she was taken Ill; and I have# a Box of Snuff is Infallible against the Megrims.

DIV3.STAGE: Offers a Box to Lady Gaylove; she strikes it out of his hand; he feels for it under the Couch, touches Careless and Crys out. Lady Gaylove starts from the Couch.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: Ruin'd, Undone, oh Wretched Fortune!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ant.
SP.P: Ah, what's the Matter!—

SP.SPEAKER: Dan.
SP.P: The Devil, I think.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: Nay, indeed this Room is Haunted; and now they say, the Spirit is so bold, 'twill come at Noon-Day.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ant.
SP.P: And why wou'd you offer to bring Cocky here? I'm sure if she shou'd see a Ghost, 'twou'd utterly ruin her.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Lov.
SP.P: Let us be gon, pray Dear; I am afraid to stay a Minute longer.

SP.SPEAKER: Dan.
SP.P: Don't be frighted, Ladies; I'gad, what I felt, was alive and warm.

DIV3.STAGE: Dandle Peeps, and the Ladies pull him away.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: Fy, how can you be so Presumptious!

SP.SPEAKER: Dan.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha; Gad I shall burst with Laughter; 'tis Careless▪ Dearest Rogue, come out of your Hole, Sir James will hugg me for this Discovery; he loves Mischief dearly, when it don't light on him self.

DIV3.STAGE: He pulls the Couch away and throws down Sir James.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ant.
SP.P: Ah, Basilisk, Harpy, am I, say, am I, a! and are these your Spirits! Oh, my Head now!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Now, have not I one Lye ready for an Excuse!

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Till that Rogue, Dandle, is Murder'd, nothing will Prosper.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: How, in the Name of Wonder, got you here; this is a Plot upon my Reputation, a Confederacy against me!

SP.SPEAKER: La. Lov.
SP.P: I am all Amazement!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ant.
SP.P: At the Discovery, Minks: Oh, that I shou'd live to see this Day!

SP.SPEAKER: La. Lov.
SP.P: I hope, Dear, you don't suspect my Innocence!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ant.
SP.P: Don't speak, let Shame keep thee slent.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Lov.
