SP.P: Nay, if you are so positive, I'll leave you, and give you time enough to see your Errour; tho', perhaps you may see it too late.

SP.SPEAKER: Dan.
SP.P: Gad, I am afraid I have made good a Saying of Anti∣quity, and pull'd an Old House o'er my Head.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ant.
SP.P: I suppose, Madam, this was one of your Decorums?

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: Fly, and don't provoke me, for I am all Fury!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Madam, I Humbly—

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: Peace, not a Word; you can say nothing will excuse such Rudeness; I guess Lucy was brib'd to Conceal you, that you might over∣hear our Discourse, being vain enough to fancy your selves the Subject; but you found your mistake; and now be gon, let me never see you more; nor that Slanderer, Sir Anthony; nor that Brute, Dandle; nothing Thrives where such Company frequent.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ant.
SP.P: By'r Lady, I don't know what to think!

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: I ll go learn the bottom of this Design, and then I shall know how to be Reveng'd.

SP.STAGE: Sir James makes Horns over Sir Anthony's Head, and drives him out: Careless Drives out Dandle, and Kicks him as he goes.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE Changes to Sir James's Lodgings.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Sure, that Spanish Enchantress has set a Spell on me; nothing else is in my Thoughts, nor no other Intrigue will prosper. Well, had I any hopes she wou'd be mine, I think I cou'd be Constant, and forsake Rambling.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Gravely spoke; but here comes one will divert thy Melancholly.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Ay, I see 'tis in vain to hope being honest, till we are past Temptation; prithee, be gon and pacify Sir Anthony; this Dear, un∣known, had almost made me forget my Assignation.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Court.
SP.P: Sir James, You must believe this a Favour.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: I Do, and Design to thank you as I ought.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Court.
SP.P: Did my Lord think me so Despicable, that none would help me to Revenge his Perjury?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir. Jam.
SP.P: Did he fansie such Beauty cou'd live neglected, because he want∣ed Judgment, mistaken Wretch? but we shall be even with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Court.
SP.P: And, which is the greatest Pleasure, in his own way.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: True, my Dear Angel, that's the greatest Pleasure—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Court.
SP.P: Ah, Sir Jam. is this like a Man of Honour, to Expose me?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Madam, as I live, I am all Surprise, I Expected no Interruption. Indeed my Servants are not taught to deny Ladys Entrance, and my Joy to See your Ladyship, made me forget to Lock this Door.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: Then you wou'd have been Lock'd up together, if I had not come and prevented your Wickedness? A fine Confession!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Malicious Gypsie; but I'll fit thee if I can. Madam, Is this well done?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Court.
SP.P: What can she mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Ay, pray Explain your Self.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: Perfidious Man, have you forgot your Marriage Vows to me? Madam, avoid him as you wou'd your Fate; he seeks but to undo, and then forsakes; perhaps he conceal'd his Marriage, and by his Arts perswade you to Love him. Alas! what will not Men do to gain their Ends?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Court.
SP.P: I'm all Confusion.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Madam, believe her not; trust me 'tis false; this Lady is my Sister Angliana Espaniola de amora; my Father went Embassadour to Spain, and there begot this fair Impertinence, born to the Native malice of her Climate; who because she has her self resolv'd to dye a Maid, proceeds to hinder me from Love, and Watches all the day blast my Joys.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: Romantick tale, Dear Madam View me, have I a Spanish look, or is my Speech Imperfect? Base and Ingrateful to Disown me thus. But, Madam, you I hope have more Humaniy, than to assist his Wrong, as yet you stand Excused, I know his false deluding Words, his faithless Vows, and soft be∣traying Glances. Oh! may they ne'er have power to Ruin more! Madam, be warn'd, fly from him as you wou'd from a fierce Basilisk. Remember he is mine, and never see him more.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Court.
SP.P: Madam, I shall obey, and am glad I Escape so well.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: What are we in a Womans hands? But I will most unmercifully Revenge me on thee for this Mischief.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: Keep your Distance, I have a Guard without; which on the least Noise will Enter, and then you lose me forever.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Then have you the Conscience to fright away a kind yeilding Mistress, and not supply her Place, without vanity I am sure you Love me.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: I can't deny, but I have a hankering Mind to that unstable Heart; for I'm resolv'd you shall have no other Mistress yet a while.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Do you Comply and I will have no other, that Blush consents, and these bewitching Eyes in tender Language say I shall be blest.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: Oh, you must sigh, and wish and languish ere I yeild. Favours too cheaply given, are thrown away.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Believe me I'm a Man of better Sence, I know how to Receive a Blessing, which is so much more Valuable for being easily Purchased, let stu∣pid whining Fools pursue the Coy, and Worship cold Disdain and haughty Scorn, give me the smiling, easie, soft, consenting Fair, that yields without the trouble of a Siege.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: Sure we were made on Purpose for each other, our Humours so ex∣actly fit, we shall both love to the same height of Extravagance, both grow weary of one another at the same Minute, and then after an airy Whirl through the Pleasant round of Variety, we shall meet again, I with new Charms to tempt, and you with new Gallantry to Conquer.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Exquisite Charmer; but I shall listen till I loose my self; come let's Retire where I may Love, Adore and Swear and Languish, forgetting all the World, but my bright Goddess.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: Yet stay, before I give up all, methinks I wou'd fain know whe∣ther you wou'd not do something more for me than for another.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: A Thousand thousand times, you cannot doubt it; retire first, then bid me Hang or Drown, or send me of an Errand to the Antipodes, your Humble Servant shall fly to oblige you.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: I have a whisical Request in my Head for the present, grant this, and then it shall be your t to Command, wait a Moment, and I'll send a Chair for you, ask no Questions, but Submit to their Disposal, and be this Ring the Pledge of our meeting with Pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: I wou'd obey, but I've a thousand things to urge against it. What Vanished? you sha'n't Escape me so, I shall soon o'er take you, or from this time, I deserve to live Honest.

DIV3.STAGE: [As he is going out Enter Lady Loveman.]

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Lov.
SP.P: Turn back with me, for you'll never overtake her, the Lady flies as if she feared your Violence, 'twas like to be no Rape I hope?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: No, Madam, a Woman's never to be Ravisht against her Will.

A Pox of her ill tim'd Visit, if this be Variety, I think I shall
grow sick on't, and rather Choose to be Confin'd to one, than thus to be tan∣taliz'd by the whole Sex.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Lov.
SP.P: Sir James, I am in Love with your Humour, and Design to Borrow just as much of it, as is convenient for a Woman; that is, I intend to be very Gay, ramble a while and defie Matrimony. What think you of the Frolick?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Well, thanks to my Stars, I shall never Sigh long for the absent, here's a Lady now fit for my Purpose, ripe and ready. Satan knew I cou'd not fast till I came to that mad Baggage, and therefore kindly sent this to stay my Stomach. Dear, Madam, I approve your Thought, and will consult with you in Private how to Improve your Diversion. Come let's be happy, here we are Secure.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Lov.
SP.P: With your Leave, I have resolv'd to be Honest, sure 'tis not Impossible to be Gay and Innocent?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: No, but this way you'll pull a Judgment upon your Head, to raise our Expectations, and then to Deceive us in my opinion is the Greatest of Sins.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Lov.
SP.P: I had best go, if I stay longer I am in Danger of being Con∣verted.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: I know you will be Mine, you can't refuse me, but don't Delay, I am Impatient and can wait no longer.

SP.SPEAKER: Chair.
SP.P: If you are Sir James Bellmont, this Chair waits You.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Short and pithy, you see, Madam, how Dangerous 'tis to Pleasure, now if you have a Mind to me, Curse your own obstinacy▪
How! The Chair darkn'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Chair.
SP.P: Yes by the Lady's Order that sent us.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Yet I'm Resolv'd in spight of every contradicting Thought, the Lady's Young and Lovely, and 'twere no hazard to go to her by Witch∣craft.
SP.STAGE: [ Carried off, and Drops a Letter.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Lov.
SP.P: His Indifferency makes me mad in my Conscience, a little more Experience, and I shall Love my Husband, What's here—
SP.STAGE: [Takes up the Letter and Reads it.

DIV3.STAGE: —My Lord has Injured me, Sworn to Requite him. If you'll be within this Afternoon I'll be with you, for I have Chose you for my Second, 'tis easie Espousing the Cause, where there is no Danger, I know you a Friend to Lady's, and cannot fear but you will Oblige your Languishing
DIV3.P: 'Tis well, this may be of Use, and my Affront may be returned, thus Mischief still goes on.

Q.L: And 'tis in vain alas! we hope for Rest
While Love, or Envy, harbours in the Breast.

DIV3.TRAILER: The End of the Third A C T.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT IV. SCENE I.
DIV2.STAGE: Enter Squire Gaylove and Nurse, and Servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Sq. Gay.
SP.P: WELL, Nurse, when will the rest of my things come? Say; I long to be a Beau. This Sword, Nurse, sa, sa, fags, I'm a hap∣py Man.

SP.SPEAKER: Nurse.
SP.P: Ay Master, so you are, for now you're fallen into good Hands, look'e here comes your Retinue to new furbish you, as one may say.

DIV2.STAGE: Enter Taylour, Periwigg-Maker, Shooemaker and Semstress.

SP.SPEAKER: Sq. Gay.
SP.P: Soa they be come, faggs I'm most ashamed.

SP.SPEAKER: Tay.
SP.P: Sir, here's a Coat cut and made to a Hair of the Mode, I hired Three French Journeymen on purpose.

SP.SPEAKER: Sq. Gay.
SP.P: Goodlack—Nay I vow it's fine, lay it down Friend, you shall work for me—many a fair Day I assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: Tay.
SP.P: Your humble Servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Nurse.
SP.P: My Friend, I can put it on, I have drest my Master hitherto my

SP.SPEAKER: Prig.
SP.P: Here's a Wigg was made for Beau Playmuch, to grace his new Equipage—[Aside.] But he lost all, and cou'd not pay for it. Now the Gentleman being my very good Friend, I consented you should have it as the best I ever made.

SP.SPEAKER: Sq. Gay.
SP.P: Be you sure it will fit me now, that's the Question?

SP.SPEAKER: Periwig.
SP.P: Oh! Sir, ne'er fear that, a long Wigg fits any Head.

SP.SPEAKER: Sq. Gay.
SP.P: I suppose, Mistress, you have brought my Linen.—

SP.SPEAKER: Semp.
SP.P: Yes, Sir, and hope 'tis made to please you.—

SP.SPEAKER: Sq. Gay.
SP.P: A handsome Gentlewoman truly, I could wish to tell her a piece of my mind. If you will call agen to morrow, I may set you about more Work—

SP.SPEAKER: Sem.
SP.P: Your Servant, Sir, I'll be sure to Come—

SP.SPEAKER: Shooem.
SP.P: If you please to sit down, I'll pull on your Shooes—

SP.SPEAKER: Sq. Gay.
SP.P: With all my heart, for that's a difficult Matter, my confounded Corn will make it two or three hours Work for ought I know—

SP.SPEAKER: Shooem.
SP.P: I warrant you, Sir, they'll slip on like a Glove, I am no Bungler.

SP.SPEAKER: Sq. Gay.
SP.P: So Friend, you may go—
[Aside.] They pinch wickedly, but I must keep my own Counsel, and pati∣ently squeeze my Feet to the Fashion. Come, come help me on with my Finery, I shall scarce know my self streight.

SP.SPEAKER: Nurse.
SP.P: 'Tis nicely made, Sir, and becomes you to a Miracle—

SP.SPEAKER: Sq. Gay.
SP.P: Well, good Breeding is a fine Thing, this Fellow will perswade me I look Gentile, when in my conscience I was never worse Drest in my life, if this be your French Cut, commend me to my old Taylour Slipshooe; his Work was neat and clever, this slovenly Coat whatever I Eat or Drink, will go halves with me. Let me set it right—[Puts on his Neckcloth. You may twirl it long enough, but twist it hard, and tuck it in, that will do best—

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.P: By no means, Sir, the Beaus will point at you.—

SP.SPEAKER: Sq. Gay.
SP.P: If they do, ten to one but I think like them that they point at my perfections.—[Puts on his Wigg.] Take it off quickly Friend, if I wear it, I shall neither see, nor hear; this Rogue never took measure of my Head, and now I must be forced, to wear my old Scarcrow—

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.P: Sir, your Wigg is made to a Miracle, you'll be the Envy of the Cho∣colate House—

SP.SPEAKER: Sq. Gay.
SP.P: I'm sure, say as you please, I shan't endure it, that's certain; why I can't find my way without being led, 'tis as much too big as a Riding Coat, and as heavy as a Bee-hive; pha, pha, the Hairs are all in my Mouth, I must be Dumb to prevent being Choak'd—

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.P: Be patient, Sir, Three Days will reconcile you to it, so heartily you'll admire it all Day in the Glass, and not be willing to put it off when you go to Bed.—

SP.SPEAKER: Sq. Gay.
SP.P: Well, I am perswaded, good lack, what do people suffer for the Fashion?—

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.P: One thing more and you're Compleat—

SP.SPEAKER: Sq. Gay.
SP.P: Ha! What's this?

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.P: Snuff, Sir. If you don't take this you can be no Beau.

SP.SPEAKER: Sq. Gay.
SP.P: Something to sweeten my Breath, I warrant—[Eats and sput∣ters.] Oonds the Rogue has poison'd me, ye Dog if I am to be a Beau, must I eat the Devil in Powder.—

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.P: Dear, Sir, 'twas▪purely your Mistake, 'tis to be taken up the Nose, as thus Sir.—

SP.SPEAKER: Sq. Gay.
SP.P: As thus, Sir, then why did you let me send it the wrong way.

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.P: You take too much, Sir.
SP.STAGE: [Snuffs, sneezes and Coughs, the Powder flys out of his Wigg and blinds him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sq. Gay.
SP.P: Ye Rascal I'll have you Hang'd. Sirrah, as sure as I live, you have Muther'd me▪ I am Blind, Choak'd, and Poison'd, Nurse lead me out. If I can but get to tell my Cousin, I shall dye Contented.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE. Lady Gaylove's.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: Believe me, Madam, he makes fierce Love to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Drawle.
SP.P:
Can his Gravity Condescend to talk of Love; this is most
Lucky, since I have met with such a faithful Friend, and if it come to an As∣signation, my Dear contriver.—

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: It is this Night, in a back Appartment, where my Lady seldom Comes, there I'll conceal you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Drawl.
SP.P: Oh my best Lov'd Girl, when I have caught his Sanctity tripping, how I will Triumph, make my own Conditions.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: I will Conceal you, so shall make a good Comical Jest on't, if I mistake not, but not a Word to my Lady, who I think I hear Coming.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Drawl.
SP.P: No, no, no, I'll to the Closet, and Watch thy Call.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: Do Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Drawl.
SP.P: Now Mr. Long Grace and Little Manners, to be even with thee.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Lady Gaylove and Mr. Careless.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Gay.
SP.P: Curse on all Ill Luck, I have lost more Reputation, broke more Decorums, and have had more Intrigues spoil'd within these few hours, than in my whole Life before.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: That Impertinent Fool Dandle, Sir James has Thrash'd him already, and I owe him the same Payment.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Gay.
SP.P: Surely, Sir James incourag'd him at first, only as People keep Monkyes, on Purpose to do Mischief; Lucy, no News yet of my Lady Love∣man.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: No, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Gay.
SP.P: What's become of the poor dear Creature, I wonder, she does not trust me with the Affair.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ant.
SP.P: How can you come into my House, after such Rudeness? and that Fellow will never leave, till I order my Footmen to Use him as he deserves.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ant.
SP.P: I come in Search of Cocky, I cannot Live without Cocky, that's in short.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Gay.
SP.P: You should Learn to Govern your Passion; then for my Part, I know nothing of her, upon my Honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Dand.
SP.P: Nor that Gentleman?

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: How dost thou dare Reflect, thou Insect! Hast thou no Dread of Beating before thy Eyes. I believe that Fellow will be Mummy, ere he'd part with his Darling Detraction, and his Companion Impudence—

SP.SPEAKER: Dand.
SP.P: I will stand by my Injur'd Friend, Sir Anthony.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ant.
SP.P: I thy Friend, thou art rather my Friend, always at my Elbow, puting ill Thoughts in my Head against my Cocky, I hate thee—

SP.SPEAKER: Dnd.
SP.P: So doth all the World, and yet I make a shift to live in't—

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Lady Loveman in Mens Cloaths.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Lov.
SP.P: Ha! my Husband? No matter I'll trust his Purblind Eyes; A Letter Madam, from a Friend of Yours—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Gay.
SP.P: And a pretty Messenger—
Having no Luck with the Men, resolved to turn Gallant, and have at the Ladies—Very well I protest, Sir your humble Servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Lov.
SP.P: Madam, I am Yours—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ant.
SP.P: Any News from Cocky.

SP.SPEAKER: Dand.
SP.P: I think it is her Hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Gay.
SP.P: Stand off Rudness it self: Yes Sir Anthony, your Lady has took your suspicions so to Heart, that she's retired from the World; Resolves to Live in a Cell, and never behold the Face of Humane kind—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ant.
SP.P: Oh my Cocky! My Cocky! I will find her tho' her Cell were in Greenland, or in the Land of Scorch'd Africk, where the Sun ne'r Casts an Eye, as the Song says. Oh my Cocky!

SP.SPEAKER: Dand.
SP.P: Meer Trick, Sir Anthony, they all Laugh at you I'll Engage, Tom Careless knows where she is—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ant.
SP.P: If I Thought that, and my Grief despised—

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: You'll never leave, Dandle—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Lov.
SP.P: Stand by me Careless, and I'll Hector'em both

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: I warrant you little Heroe—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Lov.
SP.P: Harkee, Sir, How dare you pretend to wear a Nose on your Face, and make it your business to Defame Ladies; the Person you are so Bold with, is my near Relation, and she bid me Greet you thus—

SP.SPEAKER: Dand.
SP.P: O Lord! Sir Honour the Lady. Another Spark, I'll Engage my Life.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ant.
SP.P: Sir, are you a Kin to my Cocky?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Lov.
SP.P: Yes, Sir, who are you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ant.
SP.P: I am her Husband, Sir, her own Tony. Did she say nothing of me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Lov.
SP.P: O Yes she said, you had abused her, and bad me remember her to you, thus, and thus, Sir,

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ant.
SP.P: Oh lay, Cocky could not be so barbarous?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Lov.
SP.P: Do you think I Lye, Sir, or fail in the Message, thus and thus, she Charg'd me to serve you both. Hence ye Scoundrels, and learn to va∣lue Vertue.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ant.
SP.P: Oh! Cruel Cocky!

SP.SPEAKER: Dand.
SP.P: What's the Fellow Mad?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Lov.
SP.P: Fly ye Vipers, or my Fury shall sweep ye from the Earth.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ant.
SP.P: Gad I'll be gone, and Swear the Peace against him, and Cocky. Cocky set him on—

SP.SPEAKER: Dand.
SP.P: And I'll be Revenged!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Gay.
SP.P: Why thou'rt both for Love and War, my Charming Gani∣ede.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Love.
SP.P: Did not I strain my Voice, and roar rarely,—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Gay.
SP.P: Incomparably; now, tell us your Designs.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Love.
SP.P: For that reason I drove them hence.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Gay.
SP.P: Well, and how, and how, Dear Creature? Where hast thou been, what hast thou done in this Disguise? I'm all on fire to know.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Love.
SP.P: Oh Manhood is the prettiest thing in this World; You must know, my Dear, I have had an Inveterate Spight against my Lady Courtall, as they call her, ever since the disordering of my Favourites, and resolv'd to be reveng'd; a Letter of hers fell into my Hands, I carried it Impudently, made Love, and as Impudently succeeded.—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Gay.
SP.P: How's this, by a Letter.—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Lov.
SP.P: Ay, ay, there's no getting into a Ladys Heart like getting into her Secrets, when she's in your Power, 'tis your own Fault if you don't Command her. But, my Dear, I have done the boldest thing that ever was, sent for my Lord, and made an Assignation with his pre∣tended Wife in your outward Apartments without your Knowledge.—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Gay.
SP.P: My Life! My House is yours; but sure my Lady never will come here again.—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Lov.
SP.P: Oh she's not to know it; I meet her in a Hackney-Coach, whirl round, and talk Love till I have turn'd her Brain, then bring her in the Back-way, and Expose her; pray lend me the Key, and let Mrs. Lucy put my Lord in a Closet, do you break forth, and leave the rest to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Why ye're a very Machiavil at Contrivances.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Lov.
SP.P: Ay, but I want handsomly to be reconcil'd to my own Spouse; for really a Woman parted from her Husband, especially if he's worth Money, and will stand it out, is but a despicable thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Ladies, will you give me leave to name an Expedient.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Gay.
SP.P: With all our Hearts.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Nay, your Ladyship must join in it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Gay.
SP.P: You may be sure of me.—

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: If you would give me leave to make a Sham-Marriage with you, Sir Anthony, would no more suspect me for his Wife's Gallant, and she pretend a thousand things relating still to that, to excuse her change of Lit.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Lov.
SP.P: Excellent! Then we shall have Banter upon Banter, and Mirth in abundance.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: My Footman shall perform the Ceremony, we'll Invite Sir Antho∣ny to the Wedding, and when they are reconciled, and the Jest over, Laugh unmeasurably.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Gay.
SP.P: Ay, be sure it be your Footman then, for, Mr. Careless, I would not be Married in Earnest for the Universe; I must have no body to contradict my Ders.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Oh no, Madam, I am the Slave to your Decorums.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Lov.
SP.P: Well, this Affair is Finished now, I fly away for my La∣dy, who sits shivering in a Hackney-Coach at Charing-Cross, half dead with Cold and Expectation.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Gay.
SP.P: But do you really think she waits for you?—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Lov.
SP.P: Think! I know it; who would not wait for such a pretty young Fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Gay.
SP.P: Oh Vanity! You're a hopeful young Fellow indeed, if she comes to the bottom on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Lov.
SP.P: Pray Heaven I be'n't ravish'd in the Hackney-Coach. If I get her hither I am safe enough. Mrs. Lucy., Pray take care of my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: Yes, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Lov.
SP.P: Servant, Servant, be sure you're both ready for the Disco∣very.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Fear not your Servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Gay.
SP.P: Lucy, manage this Matter handsomly; come Mr. Careless, we'll in and play a Game at Picquet till she calls us.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: If you please, Madam.—

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy
SP.P: So, here's Intrigue upon Intrigue; but 'tis ne'er the worse for my Designs, I care not how many; see my old Canter longs for Fornication. Ha! the Bell Rings, I believe he's Bell Rings. come already; Oh these wanton Adders are sharp set, but I must dispose his Wife first against I come.

DIV3.P: Now Madam, into this Chest, and you shall hear all Passages, and make your own Advantage.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Drawle.
SP.P: Thanks, dear Lucy, I wish no more.—

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: Make haste, they Ring at this Back-door.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Drawle.
SP.P: Help me a little,—So,—So.—

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: Lie still.—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Drawle.
SP.P: I warrant you.—

DIV3.STAGE: [Goes to the Door, and lets in Lord Courtall.
DIV3.P: Lord Courtall. Pretty Mrs. Lucy, I suppose you have heard I am to be disposed of till the Charmer comes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: Yes, my Lord, in this Closet, if you please.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Court.
SP.P: Ay, ay, any where; Lady Loveman said at Six.—

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: She'll be here presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Court.
SP.P: Well, well, I'll wait her time.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: So, now for Mr. Drawle.
SP.STAGE: [Bell Rings again. Lets Mr. Drawle in.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Drawl.
SP.P: Well, Friend Lucy, I see thou'rt a Girl of thy word; say, my little Maid, art thou a Maid, hey my little Girl.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: Fye, Mr. Drawle, you are so waggish.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Drawl.
SP.P: See what I have brought thee, my Ninny, tinny, pittee, pattee, hey my little Girl, a Diamond Ring Fool, worth 80 l. Fool▪ hey.

SP.SPEAKER: Lcy.
SP.P: And what must I do for this?—

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Drawl.
SP.P: Nothing at all, nothing at all, very little or nothing at all▪ Pittee pattee; are the Doors fast, Chicken, Pippin.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy▪
SP.P: Yes, yes, give me the Ring.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Drawl.
SP.P: Give me a Buss then.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: Shaw, Shaw.—
Oh Heavens, a Key in the Back-door, I am undone.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Drawl.
SP.P: So am I; hide me somewhere, I beg of you.—

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: Under the Bed quick, quick, and I'll a top; out and cover me the Cloaths.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Drawl.
SP.P: All then's wrong, but I must submit.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Lady Loveman, and Lady Courtall.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Crt.
SP.P: Where hast thou brought me, my Dear Adonis?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Lov.
SP.P: To Lodgings of mine, where you are as safe as you can wish; Dull, dull Sir James, to lose this Treasure. But did you never toy before?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Court.
SP.P: Never; we Women that Converse, or have Conversation with several Men, never value any; Interest takes up our Thoughts, and being often deceived, we expect no Trust, nor give any. When we in∣trust a Fool, we can feign Jealousie, feign Fits, Tears, all the Passions that are useful, but in reality, nor Love, nor Hate, but as Conveniency serves: To thee sweet Youth I open all my Heart, for thou art young, unknowing yet, and I would fain secure thee mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Lov.
SP.P: But then don't you love the Lord you live with now?—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Court.
SP.P: Love him; yes, yes; I Ride in his Coach, spend his Estate, abuse his Servants, go by his Name; Love him, Oh mightily, mighti∣ly Child, but he has wrong'd me, therefore I resolv'd to be reveng'd the sweetest way.—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Lov.
SP.P: And shall; we will my Soul, my Charmer, my—

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Lord Courtall out of the Closet, Lady Courtall Shrieks.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Court.
SP.P: Ha! tho' I hate her, I'll cut your Throat you young Dog.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Lov.
SP.P: Oh! hold, I beseech ye, I am Lady Loveman,—see, see my Manhood is Counterfeit, hold, hold,—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Court.
SP.P: Ha, Betray▪d.—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Gay.
SP.P: What Noise is this in my House? What do you keep no Drum? Ha! my Lord Courtal, Lady Courtall, and a young Gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Lov.
SP.P: No faith, Madam, I can't boast of my Manhood,—a Woman I am, and have as truly shewed my self so in my Revenge, as—What say you my Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Court.
SP.P: Ay, let him speak, I knew all your Haunts before, your shallow Plots and your Designs, and did what I have done to make you more Ridiculous.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Court.
SP.P: For shame be gone,—go, where I never may behold you more.—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Court.
SP.P: Yes, I will go, and thou won't follow me, I know thy Weakness, and my Power.—Upon your Peril follow me,—howe∣ver I'll be reveng'd of that Jilt,—I know her Husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Lov.
SP.P: Do, my Lord, follow her, for I have done with you, and the intriguing part of Mankind.

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Court.
SP.P: Ha, ha, Why my Dear Lady Gaylove, was not I at the bot∣tom of this Plot?—

SP.SPEAKER: Gay.
SP.P: Upon my Honour, my Lord, 'tis New to me; this must be Lucy; I will be rid of that Wench, she'll bring a Scandal on my House else.—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Lov.
SP.P: Madam—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Gay.
SP.P: Peace, my Dear, my Decorums oblige me to dissemble with my Lord, Lucy where is she? I'll turn her out of Doors—

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: Good Madam, be not in such a Passion. Indeed, indeed I'm Innocent in this Matter; 'tis true, Mr. Drawle would needs speak with me alone, and ventureing to bring him hither, he forc'd this Diamond Ring upon me for one Buss.—

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: How, Mr. Drawle!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Gay.
SP.P: Filthy Creatures.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: And where is he now?—

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: Under the Bed and please you, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Lov.
SP.P: Ha! More than we expected; yes, Mrs Lucy, it will please me, and I'm resolv'd to see the End of this. Help a little; I'gad here is something; what Mr. Drawle the Reformer, the mender of Manners, come confess, discover your Iniquity immedi∣ately, (Pulls out Drawl. or you shall be sent thus to your Brethren▪ with Evidence of the Fact.—

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Drawle.
SP.P: I do Confess, I am overtaken, that I am Expos'd, as it were, a Scandal to the Brethren; I do also confess, that many times, when I have rebuk'd the Wicked, my self have been tempted, yea attempted by Violent Inclinations; yea, when I have sent a pretty white Transgres∣sor to the Round-house, I, even my self, have fetch'd her out again.—

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: And kept her for your own use, I suppose.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Drawl.
SP.P: Yea, Verily.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Lov.
SP.P: Here's a Rogue for you; now he's got into his Cant he goes on, tho' ▪tis against himself.—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Gay.
SP.P: 'Tis I suffer by this; how dar▪st thou come into my house with such Designs?—

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Drawl.
SP.P: I am, as it were encompassed by the Wicked, let me Escape and tell it not unto my Wife, least she rejoyce—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Drawl.
SP.P: And lay thy Hypocritical Saintship [Mrs. Drawle, Coming Open, thou false Apostle, thou greater Pretender, and out of the Chest. little Performer in Every thing, thou—

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: Hold, Mrs. Drawle, Noise is an Offence to me—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Loe.
SP.P: See the Everlasting Tub Preacher is silent, Come, Come, go Lady Gay. Home and forgive One another, that's the Only way to put a good Face on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Drawl.
SP.P: Yea, each knowing the others Infirmities, we will go Home, and live like the rest of the Married World, upbraiding One an∣other.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Drawl.
SP.P: Agreed in Dissension, and if I do'nt outwrangle thee, I'll lose my Charter of the City, and be a very Subject Wife to a Face Or∣dain'd for Horns, and a Wretch that deserves 'em. Your Servant Ladies. Come, my dear Spouse—

SP.SPEAKER: Mr. Drawl.
SP.P: Curse on your Sex, and our Weakness, that betrays us to your Sport—
SP.STAGE: Exit Mr. Drawle and Mrs. Drawle.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Gay.
SP.P: Come let's in and Laugh—and Consult Lady Lovemans Reconcilement, and then all's well—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Lov.
SP.P: Come on, methinks, I am so valiant, and so prosperous, I could make my own Conditions, and Fright'em into a Compliance.—

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Lead on little Hector—.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE Changes.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Lady Bellmont, Angelica and Valentine.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Bell.
SP.P: Success and Everlasting Fame Crown thy attempt, then ge∣nerous Maid it cannot fail. Thy Beauty, and thy Wit, will win the wild Trangressor, back to Virtue.

SP.SPEAKER: An.
SP.P: Dear Madam, be near, I hear him Coming. How! my Heart Flutters. Lady Bell. Fear nothing, we are within thy Call.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter▪ Chairman with Sir James, he runs to Embrace her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: My Angel, are we met.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: Will you not trust me for the time to Come?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Out of my sight, I cannot, I am so furiously in Love; I be∣lieve I shall grow Constant, and Change no more.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: Dare you be in Earnest?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Trust me, I have lik'd before, and Rang'd at large; gathering the Sweets of many a blooming Fair: But ne'er till now, knew what it was to Love.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: What a Secret Pleasure we receive from well Invented Flat∣tery?—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Dear Infidel!

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: Charming Deceiver!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: What do we here, to loose these precious Minutes? Come, lead me to the pleasing Scene, where I may finish my Imperfect Joys.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: Where I may give a loose to longing Love, and wind my self a∣bout your panting Heart?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Where equal transports shall Unite our Souls, and blend us in∣to one vast Ecstacy—

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: Whil'st fleeting Time unheeded passes by, and hours and days ap∣pear but one kind happy Now.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Till Waking from the pleasing Trance of Passion, we won∣der at the Age, that scap'd our Notice—

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: That Waking brings me to my self again, for then, Madam, your Servant, I would stay longer, but some Friends expect me; when I have leisure, I may Call this Way. Won't it be thus?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir. Jam.
SP.P: These be the Fears of constant doting Fools. But we that are only true to Pleasure, Think not so far. Come, prithee let us Retire.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: I would Comply, but—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Does Inclination sway, and dost thou Pause, what is it stos thee—

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: A Foolish Vow I made that the first Man I went to Bed to should be my Husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: But, Rash Vows are better broke than kept.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: I dare not yield.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: A little Force is Convenient, for that I'll not stand out with you—

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: As I am a Woman, I have the privilege to be Obstinate, and I'll not leave my Prerogative; Consent to Marry me, or quit me Instantly—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Matrimony! Thou hast frightened me into a cold Sweat; Come, take me into thy Arms, and Swear thou didst but Jest, to try my Patience—

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: I'm fixt as Fate—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Nay, then—

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: You would not accept of so poor an Entertainment, as Love com∣pell'd would give.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Trust me, I'm so sharp Set, I shan't be very Nice at pre∣sent—

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: One stamp of my Foot, with ease can set me Free. Therefore quick∣ly say, will you Consent? It's but a trifle we Contend for; Marry, and when y're Cloy'd, forsake me, and be at Liberty, as great as E∣ver—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P:
I Gad, thou hast Conquer'd, I can't leave thee without an hour in Private; thou bright Inchanter, boast of thy subtle Power; I that have
at all thy tempting Sex, been long acquainted with their fond their Pride and Scorn, their Patches and their Paint; at last am Yet 'tis but for an hour, a Flask of Sherry will drown the Memory, Free. Yours Ever.
Then you will Venture—

SP.SPEAKER: ir .
SP.P:
I must; thou'st wound me up to the last eager Minute, and the Prodigal, I stake the All—I've lost my Liberty, for One N ghts Happiness—Which if I Win—
The cheerful Dawn, my Freedom shall Restore,
Nor Love, nor Marriage, be remembered More.
The Victory is ours, and the Triumphant Maid.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady el.
SP.P: Has now secured the Wanderer—Oh, no, he must drink a deep Draught of Sorrow first, e're he is weaned from these vain Plea∣sures—
Madam, will ye not Mask'd, be Witness to the Wedding—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady .
SP.P: Yes, and Heaven prosper it, as my Design is Vertuous; you'll Come—

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: When 'tis over, I have a Turn too, which I hope, will make me happy—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady B.
SP.P: My Neice Marina I suppose. Success attend you—Exit.
Come, my fair Runagate, has all my Arguments prevailed, are you Convinc'd your Mother wrong'd ye, as I Love you—

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: You▪re the first Person, in my confin'd Conversation I ever heard speak Reason; therefore, 'tis Natural I shou'd believe ye.

And can you Love me too, and will you Marry me, for that's the Only way to be Secured against your Mothers Plots. I must confess, I mtion this abruptly, but I mean honestly, and Our time is short; there∣fore Pardon d Forms—

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I have done so much already, to deny what Ever you with Reason ask; I▪m sure, I Love you; and I think, I'm sure Marriage will not make my Portion less—

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: Generous Maid! 'twas so of Old, without dull Ceremonious Forms, kind Lovers met—without long Settlements, and Joyntures made by the Scribling Scribe, the Consenting Pair was happy: They're Coming, Dear How am I Blest!
I tremble, tho'—Away, my Love shall drive thy Causeless Fears from thee—

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Sir James, Angelica, and Harriot.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Well, thou Angel! thou something more Charming, than the Earth affords—Now you have made me do a foolish thing; give me the right reward that Love requires, Beauty like yours sets every Pulse a beat∣ing, and gives Desire; a Rage not to be born—Come, My little Gypsie, where's your Ladies Bed-chamber, where's the Altar, that I may offer all the eager Fruits of Deathless Love—

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: There, Sir, there's the tempting, Scene. 'Umph it almost makes my Mouth Water—

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE Draws and shows a Bride-bed.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir. Jam.
SP.P: Come, My fair Nymph, let your Hands be as nimble as your Tongue, and quick Dispoil my Goddess of these useless Ornaments; What not a falling Syllable to bless your eager Lover; thus let me Embrace and make thy Wishes sweet as blooming Roses—and silent as yielding Maids—Come, Mrs. Pert, Methinks you're very tedious—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Har.
SP.P: Oh! my Lady will be undone in a Minute; truely you an't very forward, there's a Night Gown for you—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Speak, my Charmer? Why dost thou Blush [Takes of his Sword, lays it on the Table. and Weep—

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: I'm thinking, what a mad Thing we have done, and Repentance will o'retake the Frolick, and soure all our Joys—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Prithee, let's not reflect on any thing but Pleasure. No, I like not that, sure thou dost mean me fair. That [Harriot carries the Sword out of the Room. lovely Face, the Work of Heaven, can't harbour Treachery.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: Ha! Suspected, then 'tis sure, if you'd have been safe you should have trusted me—Now your best Harriot—Call my Janisaries.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Hold, little Fairy, first give me back my Sword or—

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: Yes, Sir, Yes, they shall bring it you.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Three or four Men, who snatch up Sir James, blindfold, and hurry him off.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: Away with him—

SP.SPEAKER: Har.
SP.P: Ha, Ha, What does he think now? Well I cou'd never have don't to the Man I Loved, I should have gone to Bed, and tryed to Re∣form him there—

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: Peace Idleness—▪

LG.L: Sure the just Powers will Prosper my Design,
Since this wild Reprobate by Contracts mine,
I love him, and if in Vertue there be Charms,
I▪ll fix the Wanderer in these faithfull Arms.

DIV3.TRAILER: The End of the Fourth ACT.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT V. SCENE II.
DIV2.STAGE: Enter Lady Gaylove, Lady Loveman, Careless, and Lucy, all in Mas∣querade.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: PRithee what kind of Figures do we make?

SP.SPEAKER: La. Lov.
SP.P: Very Frolicksome ones, I assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: Why we are going about a grand Frolick, Matrimony; but we shall have the Sweet Meat without the Sour Sauce; for every Wedding begins pleasantly, and ours will end before we have time to change; Dear Careless, we shall never Brawl, for we Marry in Jest.
That's my Misfortune.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: I would not Marry in Earnest for the Universe; a Married Woman is never trusted with a Secret, and I could not live without know∣ing all the Secrets of the Town, and then perhaps the Fellow I gave the Privilege to call me Wife, would grow Insolent, and be Jealous, tho' he only Married me to Cheat my Children, and that I can do better my self, and therefore am resolv'd to be Absolute.—

SP.SPEAKER: La. Lov.
SP.P: Still I am afraid of that Devil Dandle; if he is not amus'd, we shall never succeed.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: Lucy, I have just now a Thought come into my Head; hast thou a mind to a Husband.—

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: If it suits with your Convenience, Madam. (Lucy Aside, Strok∣ing her Belly down.) I am sure your Ladyship's Service has given me occa∣sion for one.—

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: Well then, when Sir Anthony believes our design of Marry∣ing, in disguise find out Dandle, and whisper it as a Secret to him; I know the Wretch has a Mind to me, that is, my Money, and if thou dost but promise him the Habit of Careless, he is easie to believe in his own good Fortune, and will catch at the Bait: I leave it to your Management, Lucy, and you know he has an Uncle must give him an Estate one time or another.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Lov.
SP.P: And let her be tied the same gentle way your Lady∣ship designs with Mr. Careless, and if they do not like, she may for a piece of Money, slip the Noose, give him his Liberty, and redeem her own.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: I am overjoy'd at the Contrivance—

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Let us away, that you may about it presently; the quickest Project always proves best.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE Changes.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Sir James Bellmot, follow'd by two or three Footmen.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Where are you all, you Lazy Vermin, born to Devour, but never ready to Serve; ye are the Lumber of the World, the only useless stock of the Creation.—

SP.SPEAKER: Footm.
SP.P: An't please your Honour—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Nothing will ever please me more, fly Dog, those Chair∣men, that close Chair, not you, Rascal, that are so fat with swilling Ale, and sleeping on Tavern Benches; thy Legs won't carry thee half a Street, Porpoise.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: What, in a Passion, Sir James?—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Ah! Valentine, Look upon me as the last of Men. Confu∣sion! I to be Fool'd, Spanish Tricks in England; I shall grow mad if I am not reveng'd.—

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: I thought nothing could have shook your Temper thus—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: S'death, I thought so too; but there was a Woman, An∣gel, or Devil, I know not which to call her; Fair as the first, and Sub∣tle as the last; a lovely Innocence o're-spread her Face; Wit and Fire revell'd in her Eyes, and dwelt upon her Tongue; she had a Thou∣sand Charms, and I ten Thousand Flames, and when she had wound me up till my Desires grew my Masters, then no less Bribe than Ma∣riage would be accepted.—

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: No more, I know the Story, and blush to think on't; you are Ruin'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: I fear I am; yet had it been by any other Means, I could have born it better.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: Sir James, How have I Loved you, witness the many Hazards I have run in Spain, and France, and here your Wildness has brought my Life a Thousand times in Danger.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Well then, consider Valentine what I have endured from thy Grave Counsels, thy serious Admonitions, the prevention of many a sweet Intrigue, because you have thought it Dangerous or Wicked; yet spight of this Severity, I love thee more than all the loose Com∣panions of my Youth; I cannot quit my Darling Pleasures. Pleasure's the End of Life, and whilst Health and Vigour last, I must pursue it.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P:
Thou shouldest have added Wealth, Unhappy Libertine. How soon will Pleasure fly thee; I see the wretched Fate that is coming
on thee: Farewell, if we ne'er meet again, then too late you may repent your hasty Marriage.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Hey Day, what's the meaning of this, Valentine? Grave Philo∣sophy has turned his Brain, that's certain; 'tis not one in ten of these Hypochondriacks escape that stately Mansion in Moorfields; but he seems to know my Blessing of a Wife, else how came he acquainted with th' Affair; 'tis all a Riddle, and I'll think no more on't: What must I do? the Plague on't is, I have no Money; I'll e'en send to these Lucky Rogues that have won it, and Borrow till Sir Anthony lets me have some more. Who Waits?

SP.SPEAKER: Serv:
SP.P: Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Step to Mr. Lamour, and desire him to lend me a Hun∣dred Guineas till to Morrow.—

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Is't come to this? I'll provide for my self, lest he should Borrow of me; his Service has made me pretty warm, but I shall not be such a Fool as to part with it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Hah! Confusion rises in my Face: What do I behold! my Mother, how could she find me out? I must set a good Face on't however; Madam, You are welcome to a Young Fellow's Lodging; what shall I Treat you with?—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Bell.
SP.P: I have brought my self the Entertainment, how you will like it, I know not: I hear you are Married Son, I give you Joy.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: What a Devil, has this little Gipsy had it Cry'd?—

SP.SPEAKER: La. Bell.
SP.P: You see by my Indifference your Actions have no longer Power to disturb me; all the Passions that have rack'd my Soul since thy unhappy Birth, are now no more; Love, Pity, Fear, Anger, all are hush'd, my Eyes are open, and I behold thee as a Trifle purchas'd almost with Life, not worth my Care, what wakeful Nights, and Melancholy Days have I endur'd for thee; but it is past, this last Act has compleated my Care, and left thee no room in a Mother's Breast.—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: That's a Shocking Thought; but Madam, I'm a Great Boy, and must bear my Afflictions as I may.—

SP.SPEAKER: La. Bell.
SP.P: No, I suppose I have not touch'd thee there yet, but I have still a Lash will make thee smart; thy Estate is so Incumber'd, thou canst not raise another Penny, and what you might expect from me, I have put beyond your Reach and mine; that Lady whom I mention'd to you for your Wife upon your Refusal, I have adopted for my Daughter, and upon her settled all the Wealth I have with∣in my Power; therefore never more hope the least Advantages from thy long Injur'd Mother.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam
SP.P: So, when the Devil and Fortune begin to kick a Man down Stairs, they never leave till he is at the Bottom; hang it, this little En∣chantress runs more in my Head than all my other Misfor∣tunes.—

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Mr. Lamour gives you his Service, but says he has just lost all his Money at Marybone, and so said Mr. Townbred, that was with him.—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Ungrateful Dogs; but 'tis no matter, I'll to Locket's, sure my Credit will serve me for Champaign, and there I'll drown these Melancholy Thoughts; follow me thither.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: By and by.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: There's a true Sign of Poverty; my Servants grown Saw∣cy already. Patience, I shall need thee I perceive.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Sir Anthony Dandle, and two Bayliffs.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: Yonder he goes, Snap him; the Action's a Thousand Pound.

SP.SPEAKER: Bayliffs.
SP.P: I warrant you. Lord, what a World of these well-dress'd Fellows fall into our Clumsie Fists. Come Brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: My Lady Bellmont has sent me word, she will pay no more of her Son's Debts; and I have a Bond, besides the Mort∣gage, so his handsome Limbs shall pay for it. I hate these young Fellows, mortally hate them, since Cocky loves them so well.

SP.SPEAKER: Dand.
SP.P: Ay, indeed, she has done basely.—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P:
Basely! Pray what has she done to you? I wont hear Cocky abus'd neither, has she wrong'd any body but my self? Besides there are worse Wives. I never took Diet-Drink long of Cocky; there are good Men, substantial Neighbours of mine,
Mr. Dandle, have done that, and forgiven their Wives too, I'll tell you that.

SP.SPEAKER: Dand.
SP.P: You are a Whimsical Man, Sir Anthony, you'll neither▪let me Praise your Wife, nor Rail at her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: No body shall Rail at her but my self, Sir, and that's enough; Mr. Dandle, I have earnest Business, you have follow'd me all this Day, and I must in plain terms tell you, I must be rid of you, and there's too much for you Sir, and so your Servant Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Dand.
SP.P: A strange▪ obstreperous Fellow this is; but in my way of Living▪ I meet with many such Affronts.
I have watch'd the Critical Minute, and it is as I could wish.—

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: Pray Sir, know you where Sir Anthony is? I was told he was here.

SP.SPEAKER: Dand.
SP.P: I know that Voice, he is gone, but my Dear Mrs Lucy, can't I serve your Turn.—
Mr. Dandle, I profess I did not mind 'twas you; my Business is with Sir Anthony, at this time.

SP.SPEAKER: Dand.
SP.P: Come, do the true Office of thy Profession, and disclose the Secret to me; I believe I am the first thou hast met, and that's a License; what News from the Forlorn Hope! the Wife.—

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: Well, you was ever a prevailing Man on me, Mr. Dandle.

SP.SPEAKER: Dand.
SP.P: And so was every Man thou saw'st, upon my Conscience. What Contrivance is in hand, Dear Damsel?

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: Such Plots, Marriages in Masquerade; Mr. Careless is just going to Marry my Lady, but I could bob him if I would, I faith; and if I knew e'er a Proper, Handsome Young Man, for I am a going for the Masking Habits, and I could pop another in his Place, as easie as Pin up a Favourite, Ha, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Dand.
SP.P: And don't you know ne'er a proper Young Man, Mrs. Lucy?

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: No, just now all the Fortune-wanting Fellows are out of my Head.

SP.SPEAKER: Dan.
SP.P: What, no Thoughts towards your Humble Servant. Come Mrs. Lucy, if you can contrive this, a Thousand Pounds is your own, and Dandle thy Eternal Slave.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: In truth, a Lucky Thought; Have me into a Private Place, and I'll Intrust you.—

SP.SPEAKER: Dan.
SP.P: With all my Heart; to Marry Lady Gaylove, to have her Estate, and Plague her, would be the greatest Blessing could befal me; come this way, I have Fifty Thousand Private Places.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: And I dare venture my self in every one of them with Mr. Dandle.

SP.SPEAKER: Dand.
SP.P: Allons.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: No Rest, no Peace for me! Cocky is unkind, and I shall go Mad; I can neither Eat nor Sleep; whatever I lay out of my Hand is Lost. By Lady 'tis well if Sir James's Bond b'en't gone; no, that's here.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: Now, who shall venture to begin first?

SP.SPEAKER: Carel.
SP.P: If there be any Danger, 'tis fit I oppose it, Sir Anthony: I am glad to meet with you; I have a Request, I hope you will not deny.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: Request me no Requests, but tell me where Cocky is, that I may go and Kill my self before her obdurate Eyes, and make her re∣pent her Falshood.—

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: We are come to offer an opportunity of Reconcilia∣tion.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: I will not hear it, be gone I say; 'tis against my Honour to think of it: O Cocky, how art thou fallen, and how am I undone; to run away in Mens Cloaths, Oh Monstrous!

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: I am sure I can witness to her Innocence, and 'tis ill done of you to talk thus.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: Ay, you were the Contriver of this for Cocky; Cocky could never Invent to run away from her poor Dear after such a termagant Manner.

SP.SPEAKER: Carel.
SP.P: On my word Sir Anthony, 'twas only an Innocent Frolick, to revenge her self on Dandle for making Mischief, as for her Dress, you see we are all in Masquerade, and I hope to prevail upon you to be the same within this Hour.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth▪
SP.P: And then to Kick, and pull People by the Nose.

SP.SPEAKER: Carel.
SP.P: All in Jest; forget it, forget it Sir Anthony.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: Tho' she did seem something Robust, I could see her fa∣vour you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ant.
SP.P: Nay, as for that, I believe, I was more afraid than hurt, and if I cou'd be Convinc'd, she had behav'd her self like a Man every way perhaps, I might be pacify'd, but Mr. Careless, and Sir James, know with what I suppose; and have generously Club'd for the Increase of my Family; well I shall be Distracted, I'll go make my Will, provide for the Poor, leave them Nine pence a Year for ever; set my House in Order, and be Carried to Bedlam.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Gay.
SP.P: First hear me; Mr. Careless is the only Man your Wife has Converst with, since the left you, and his Affections were so much an others, that he is come to Invite you to the Wedding.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: This Lady is the dear Object of my Passion, and we only have been your Ladys Companions in this Harmless affair, the Wedding is to be in Masquerade, and her Dress was only in Compliance to our In∣trigues.—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ant.
SP.P: I must confess this might be, but now it cannot; 'tis impossible I should be so happy to find Cocky Innocent.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Gay.
SP.P: Ah! Cruel Man she Loues you too well, she is a Treasure you can ne'er deserve; therefore be kinder forgive your fansied wrongs, fly to her soft Arms, and make amends for this Distrust.—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ant.
SP.P: No, I am Cold as water, Deaf as wind, and Pitiless as fire; she has been False, and as I am a City Knight, I should not pardon—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Gay.
SP.P: This News will break her Heart, she will not Live to upbraid you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: That melts me, for in my Conscience if she died by my un∣kindness, I should hang my self, and that's an undecent Death.

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: He relents.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: Well, let Lady Gaylove, that well wisher to Intrigues, the chief Joyner in Court and City, be her self joyned in Matrimony with your amorous Beauship, that both may be employ'd at home, that she may not have leisure to contrive, and you to compleat Cuckoldom, and I am Content.

SP.SPEAKER: Care.
SP.P: We are just going to be Married, and are come to intreat your Company—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Gay.
SP.P: You are so forward, my Heart misgives me—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ant.
SP.P: Let this Wedding be over, and by our Lady, I shall be in a rare Humour; I am resolv'd to Release Sir James; Come let's go, this done Cocky, you and I are Friends.—

SP.SPEAKER: Car.
SP.P: Lead the way Sir Anthony, as becomes your Gravity on this feign'd Marriage, no Repentance waits.

LG.L: Sure I may dare to prove a chearful Bride,
When with such ease the Knot may be Unty'd.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE Changes.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Sir James Arrested by two Bayliffs.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Who fears not to do Ill, yet fears the Name,
And free from Conscience, is a slave to Fame. You Catchpoles, do you understand Heroicks, answer me Harpies, are the Verses good—

SP.SPEAKER: Bayl.
SP.P: Come, Come, Sir James, leave Fooling, send for Bail, or we must have you to a worse Place.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Why Sirrah, thou hast swill'd down a Gallon of Sack for thy Share, till my Man returns with whom I have sent to see for—Friends, Bloodsuckers, Friends, are hard to be found when a Man is in Distress; Call for more Sack for them, the Rogues will Drink the Cel∣lar dry, before 'twill affect their Heads, Oh! Here he comes; well what News—

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Sir, Mr. Valentine is no where to be found, Mr. Lamour, and Mr. Townbred said, they were ingag'd to go to a Ball, and therefore could not come; three Gentlemen▪ more I went to, but to no purpose, one that you daily used to supply with Money, before his Father dyed, and now, he shook his Head, said he was sorry, but he had Forsworn being Bound or Bail for any Man.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Where's Richard, I bid him come to me—

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Ay Sir, but he has made up his Pack and is gone; I believe he has pillaged your Things, for I find all your Trunks and Drawers open—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Very well, did you go to Sir Anthony.—

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: He is not at Home, but I left word for him—

SP.SPEAKER: Bail.
SP.P: I find Sir James, there is no hope, and when we have ended our Sack, we must remove.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: As I came back I saw my Lady, your Mother, I stopt the Coach, and told her your Condition, she said she would Instantly be here—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: There, thy officious Care has been too busie; Here lead me to Prison, I had rather be Condemn'd to the blackest Dungeon, then bear her just Reproach.—

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Sir, she is here.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Bell.
SP.P: What Dumb, no Jest, no Railery, no Encomium on Vice, nor Invective against Sobriety; then Adversity reforms?—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: I am the same, only a Cup too low, the Rogues swallow'd up my Share of the Sack; I was thinking how to be even with them—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Bell.
SP.P: You have another Cause to be dejected, or I am misinform'd, you've Lost your Bride.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: I hope Madam, you know where she is, for I have a longing mind to a Wedding Night.—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Bell.
SP.P: Send for your Creditors, and throw amain, perswade them to be kind, and Play on Honour a Lucky hit, would give you back your Liberty; then seek your Wife where Strumpets use to Haunt, where Poverty and vile Diseases reign, by this Direction you'll be sure to find her—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: E'gad Madam, this is hard to believe; I like her well e∣nough to think her Honest, I am unwilling to change my opinion, especi∣ally, before Consummation.—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Bell.
SP.P: You'll find I tell you true, by a most Fatal proof.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Dear Madam, be expeditious, Bail me and Pay my Fees instantlẏ, for I am upon the Rack to know how Matters go—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Bell.
SP.P: Vain Reprobate, do not mistake my visit, I am not come as a Friend, to set thee Free, but to overwhelm thee with more ponde∣rous Ruin.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: See the Impertinent Rage of Woman-kind. Madam, you come too late; Fortune has Forestall'd you▪ I know the worst, and can Sit down and Laugh at it; You know the old Story of Diogenes, he liv'd in a Tub, my Tenement may happen to be Larger; I fansie I am grow∣ing a great Man, when I am serious, I'll be a Stoick, and vent grave Sen∣tences against Wine and Women, despising every Blessing. I can't pos∣sess; when I am Angry I'll be a Poet, and write a Satyr against Money, when Merry I'll think over my past Frolicks, and in Sprightly imagi∣nation act them over again, and tast the Pleasures twice, then still I'll have the Box and Dice, and one Hand shall Play against t'other to prevent Idleness.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Bell.
SP.P: When thou art Sad, as sure thou wilt through the long variety this Sable Hour may afford, then Mourn thy Friends hard Fate; poor Valentine thy Friend, the only Man would wear that Title; he lov'd thee next his Soul dearer than Life, for that alass he has lost, and for thy sake.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Pardon my Interruption, for I am Mad, and cannot un∣derstand his Doubtful Meaning. Valentine Kill'd!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Bell.
SP.P: He is.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: By whom?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Bell.
SP.P: Some Hector that was sent to find you out, and force you to acknowledge the Debts your Strumpet Wife has Contracted.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: 'Tis Witchcraft all; I'll not believe a word, and yet it makes strange Impression on me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Bell.
SP.P: Here stands a Mournful Witness.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: My Master, when he had received his Fatal Wound, sent me, if possible, to find you out, and begg'd, without delay you would come to him, but lest you came too late, he gave this Ring, requesting you would wear it for his Sake, that haply it might mind you to Reform.—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir. Jam.
SP.P: This to thy Memory, thou best of Men, poor Valentine, but have I Patience to repeat thy Name? Give me my Liberty again, ye Hell-hounds, that I may search the VVorld to find his Murtherer.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Bell.
SP.P: Now hate thy self, and Curse thy Guilty Follies; reflect how dear they have Cost thy Friend. A Prison, a Prison will allow thee time for Thought, and Pinching want will fit thee for the Pur∣pose.—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Hah! My Eyes are open at last, I see the wretched Maze I have trod.—Oh! that Sincere Repentance e're should come too late.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Bell.
SP.P: Alas! I fear your Penitence is feign'd; and if again you had it in your Power, again you would pursue your wild Extrava∣gance, and Glory in your Vices.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Could the Truth I am going to assert, but 'wake my Friend from his Eternal Sleep, I would repeat it till my Voice were Spent. I look upon my self with Blushing Shame, and loath the Brute I have been, but it is in vain; for I am lost, Married to a Jilt; my Dearest Friend Kill'd in my Shameful Quarrel; a Bank∣rupt in my Estate; a Jail just ready to receive me: Oh! let me think no more; eternal Lethargy dwell on my Soul, and dark Oblivion blot my Name for ever.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Bell.
SP.P: I am almost Dead.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: And are you Living? do I hold you fast my Friend?

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: My Husband!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Ha! What art thou that look'st so like an Angel? Stand off, I dare not touch thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: If Virtue, Youth and Beauty make an Angel she is one indeed: Take her to your Arms and hide her Blushes, she well deserves you.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Bell.
SP.P: Long may you Live in mutual happiness, and bring a smil∣ing race to bless my Age.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Is she not then a False one? Am I so Blest?

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: Forgive my kind Deceit 'was all well meant.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Bell.
SP.P: Have you forgot the Contract which was made between you n d the Beautiful Angelica? You were but young, yet sure you may re∣member.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P:
I do, and dare confess 'twas for that Reason I forswore the Country, lest she should claim her Right. How blind is Man thus care∣fully
to shun his greatest Blessing, and with unwearied Zeal pursue De∣struction? But how could you be thus Divinely Good, to take such Pains for one like me, unworthy?

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: My Duty and my Passion both Inspir'd me to Love you; your Character, even your Wildness pleas'd me, and Heaven has Crown'd my Wishes.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: My Life, how shall I e'er be able to reward thy wondrous Vertue!

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: Added to all the Beauties which you see, she has a Fortune large as you can wish, at her own Disposal.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: There I am lost again; for how shall I receive her; I am a Wetch, whom Vanity and Fortune have undone; could I re∣trieve what in loose Riot, and Prophane Debauchery I have thrown away, then I might meet this Fair one as I ought; now 'tis not fit these worthless Arms should hold her.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: I know both your Faults and your Misfortunes; give me your Heart, and I have all I aimed at.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Bell.
SP.P: No Money shall be wanting to tempt▪ your Happiness, I have been a Careful Mother, in hopes one day to see you reclaim'd; and have preserv'd enough to pay your Debts, and redeem your whole Estate.—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Oh Gratitude! Thou Pleasing Energy, I feel thy Influ∣ence; first, Madam, let me kneel to you, and ask your Pardon for what's past, you have given me second Life, may it answer all your Hopes.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Bell.
SP.P: I cannot speak for Tears of rising Joy.—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Then to my Lovely Bride, I promise purest and endless Truth, my Friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: He is a Bridegroom too.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Valentine Married.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: Even so, I thought it was better you should Dance at my Wed∣ding, than Sigh at my Funeral, and therefore, instead of Duelling, have yielded my self for Life to your Fair Kinswoman.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: May you both be happy, as I think my self, now Valen∣tine, for all thy long Acquaintance with the Paths of Virtue, I Chal∣lenge thee to love longer, or better than I will.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: Have a care of promising too far; I shall be angry if you break your VVord. Now I receive you but as half Converted, ex∣pecting but one corner of your Heart, yet if you make me hope, I shall grow Covetous, and grudge the smallest Part you give to ano∣ther.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: To secure all, let's consult before-hand.—

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: With all my Heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: First then, resolve to have an easie Faith; believe the best of me, for Mankind are never so honest as when you think bet∣ter of them than they deserve; they'll do a Thousand things to main∣tain a fair Opinion, when they won't do one to keep a good Con∣science.—

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: I shall oblige you, but pray then never Entertain me with Stories of your past Gallantry; let all your old Mistresses be for∣got, since 'tis many a Man's Misfortune, by repeating his own In∣trigues, either to set his Wife a Longing, or make her Jealous.—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Trust me, I shall be far from talking on my Follies, I so heartily abhor them.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: But will you never Game no more?

SP.SPEAKER: La. Bell.
SP.P: Sure you will leave that Scandalous Diversion, which rains at once both your Estate and Fame; 'tis the Trade of Sharpers, and the Shame of Gentlemen, the Destruction of Families, and the last re∣fuge of the Prodigal.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: Sir James, will you throw away the Box and Dice?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Promise then you will never have the Spleen, a Vice as natural to Women of Quality, as Gaming to the Men.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: But will you never Game more?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: I have more Antipathy to it than a Quaker to the Mode, or a Presbyterian to a Play.—

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: Methinks we are so well agreed, 'twere a Sin to doubt our Future Happiness.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Bell.
SP.P: A Thousand Joys does this Bless'd Hour give me.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: Betwixt Love and Friendship I am Lost in Pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Mar.
SP.P: I have a treble Share of all this Joy; but see, here comes Sir Anthony and's Company.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Bell.
SP.P: They are welcome.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Sir Anthony, Lady Loveman, Lady Gaylove, Mr. Careless, Mr. Dandle, and Lucy. The Women Mask'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: Sir James, I have come according to your Summons, and have brought all this Company to be a Witness of my Generosity. By Lady I'll Discharge you, and stay for my Money till you are able to Pay it: Come, let's be Merry; you see by our Dresses we are in a rare Humour. I had not Arrested you but for Lady Bellmont's Message.
Ah! Sir James, 'twas a Sign I was not at home to prevail upon my Dear to be good-natur'd before this.—

SP.SPEAKER: La. Bell.
SP.P: All is well, my Steward is coming to bring you Bills, and Money for your Debt; my Son is happy, and Married to this Fair Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: Hey, more Weddings! Why Careless is Married to Gay∣love, and I am new Married to Cocky, that is reconciled.—

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: I am amaz'd to see Marina here; what does it mean!

SP.SPEAKER: D.
SP.P: Mr Careless Married to Lady Gaylove, Hiccious Doccious, then who have I, Dear unknown, be pleas'd to reveal your self to the temera∣rious apprehension of your humble Nonentendre.
I have Languish'd for you a great while, I hope, my Dear, you'll forgive the Contrivance.

SP.SPEAKER: Dand.
SP.P: My Dear, quotha; now ten Thousand Plagues on that Jilt, For∣tune; but I am Caught, entred the Fatal Labyrinth, and no Clue left to guide me out again. Hell, Fobb'd off with a Chamber-maid, an Adjuster of Head-Dresses, a Mender of Furbeloes.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: Vermin dost murmur, thou humble Companion of Vice; thou Valet de Chambre to Iniquity, whose best quality is Cowardice; for that prevents thee from Justifying the Mischiefs thou dost, that hast liv'd on Gamesters, an under Servant to the Occupation, that never had any Reputation, but for Drinking, and Lying Inimitably.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: Truly, if I may be Judge, the Damsel has the worst Bar∣gain.—

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: So, there's another Enemy dispos'd on; this is a fortunate Night.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: Sir Anthony, you are now perfectly Friends with your Wife, and nothing now shall make a new Breach.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: Nothing!

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: Why then I am not Married, nor ever will Marry any thing upon the Face of the Earth.—

SP.SPEAKER: Carel.
SP.P: Madam, rest your self Contented, you are Married by a Priest in Orders, and here is witness enough on't, I will Possess both you and your Estate.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: Here's strange Proceedings; one Married against his Will, and another against her Knowledge.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: What, did you think to Trick Sir Anthony, and are you Trick'd your self?—

SP.SPEAKER: La. Bell.
SP.P: Sister, you're Melancholy.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Careless, I wish thee Joy.—

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: Joy! I'll have him Hang'd. I'll be Divorc'd, if there be any Law to be had. I'll take my Children and be gone; their Fortunes are in Ready Money; I'll Spend it all but I'll be reveng'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: You must ask my Leave for that, Marina's my Wife, and craves your Blessing.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: Blessing! No, I'll never open my Mouth but to Curse all my Politicks outdone, thou disobedient Girl.

SP.SPEAKER: Marin.
SP.P: Madam, I never shar'd your Kindness, nor your Love, there∣fore I hope providing for my self is no Fault.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Bell.
SP.P: Cousin, I wish you Excess of Happiness, and in me you shall find a Mother till your own is reconcil'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: Here comes another Spark to thank you for your Educa∣tion.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady Gay.
SP.P: Oh Child, thou wilt not forsake thy Mother too?

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: Faggs but I will tho'. When did you ever give me such Fine Cloaths, and look here's Gold; and Mother we have found it in the Register-Book that I am two and twenty Mother, and in ano∣ther long thing at Doctor's-Commons, that I am worth as many Thou∣sand Pounds, and so your Servant Mother; I can take Snuff now mun, Your Servant Mother.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: Ye Intolerable Buflehead.

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: She's woundy Angry.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: Be Dumb, Blockhead.

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: O la, Guardian, shall she strike me now; I have a good▪ mind to hit her again.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: No, hold, let her Passion work.

SP.SPEAKER: Carel.
SP.P: My Dear be Patient

SP.SPEAKER: La. Gay.
SP.P: May Devil, Curses, Plagues, and Disappointment light up∣on you all:

SP.SPEAKER: Carel.
SP.P: Let her go, when her Passion is at the highest 'tis to be ho∣ped she'll mend; my way shall be to search her Bags.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: How, Sir James, Can you enough return your Thanks and Prayers when you behold these Different Widows; my Lady Bellmont, the Wonder and Pattern of the Age, the other the Shame.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: VVhat I can say, is all in my Future Life, I will be only hers and yours.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Bell.
SP.P: In that my Happiness and Desires are Companions.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.P: And mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: And mine, Heaven knows.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Anth.
SP.P: Methinks I am most overjoyed that Lady Gaylove is met with, she had like to have led Cockey astray.

SP.SPEAKER: La. Lov.
SP.P: But the Danger's past now. Hear me, and believe me, I have had my Ramble, and this is the Effect: I hate the Town, de∣spise young Fellows, renounce Intrigues, and am resolv'd to love no∣thing but nown Dear as long as I live.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ath.
SP.P: By'r Lady I shall weep for Joy.

SP.SPEAKER: Dand.
SP.P: From a different motive, I shall bear you Company.

SP.SPEAKER: Lucy.
SP.P: Come set a good Face on the matter, and make a Vertue of Necessity.—

SP.SPEAKER: Dand.
SP.P: VVell, give me thy Hand; thoul't mend my Stockings, and wash my Linen, if thou art good for nothing else.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Hearty, drawing in a Footman.

SP.SPEAKER: Hearty.
SP.P: I hear News, young Masters, and Lady Friends, and this Rogue, they say, Robb'd his Master's Boxes; I have brought him along.

SP.SPEAKER: Squire.
SP.P: Mr. Valentine, is this Fine Fellow a Thief?

SP.SPEAKER: Foot.
SP.P: I hope Sir James.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Speak not; take my things, strip him, and turn him out.

SP.SPEAKER: Hearty.
SP.P: Ah Master! I hope I shall see you at Mansion-House now.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: That thou shalt, Honest Hearty.

SP.SPEAKER: Heart.
SP.P: Then 'fags we'll make the Kitchin Smoak.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.P: Gentlemen, the Musick has got notice of a VVedding, and de∣sire to give you an Entertainment.—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Let them come in.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Musick, Songs, and Dances after that.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Jam.
SP.P: Thus Bless'd with such a Lovely Fair, and all the Gifts of Liberal Fortune, vain Trifles shall no more allure my Mind, I will be always Constant.

SP.SPEAKER: Ang.
SP.P: I ever Kind.

LG.L: Madam, from you my Rule of Life I'll Vow,
Your Vertues will my Inclinations awe;
The Libertine shall now no longer Rove,
Doubly Reclaim'd by Duty, and by Love.
LOng have we suffer'd, and the injur'd Stage
Labour'd beneath the Censure of the Age:
We own our Faults, and pardon crave to day,
When we present you with a modest Play.
Here no lewd Lines offend the chaster Ear,
No Jests obscene raise Blushes in the Fair;
This we cou'd wish Collier himself wou'd hear.
'Tis purely drawn after the City Fashion,
Here's nothing taught, but thorough Reformation.
Here Vice is sham'd, and Lewdness is supprest:
Virtue's rewarded, and her Friends carest.
If some lewd Characters at first appear'd,
They're reclaim'd, or Punishment they shar'd.
The Widow Gaylove led a wanton Life,
Is she not punish'd, to be twice a Wife?
What greater Curse can on our Sex be laid,
Then to repent in earnest, and in jest to Wed?
And Cocky now grown fond of Matrimony,
Resolves no more to wheedle with her known Sir Tony.
Bellmont, who all Variety has try'd,
Yet in a Vicious Course ne'er satisfy'd;
Finds there's no pleasure like a Virtuous Bride.
How was he struck with more than common awe,
When Virtue's purer Beauties first he saw!
How did he Curse his Stars, and blame his Fate,
That he shou'd live so fast, yet know to live so late?
And you his Brethren, who to day appear
With your full Wiggs, and empty Noddles here;
Resolve like him to leave your wicked Courses,
And save your sweet Persons, and your Purses;
So Maids may be (by your assistance) Nurses.
Be once Content to take a Virtuous Woman,
You see, 'tis dangerous ranging in the Common.
Since Virtue's then our only Theme to day,
'Tis for your Honour, that you like the Play.
Oh! how would Lady Bellmont be asham'd,
To see her Libertine by you condemn'd;
Who ought as much as he to be reclaim'd.
But You, bright Circle, ne'er can be unkind,
And slight a Present to Your Sex design'd:
Angelica, however fair and true,
s but a inter Copy drawn from you.
Then rse bright Nymphs, and in our Cause appear▪
Ps hopes are centra in the Fair:
your Eyes alone Mankind is aw'd,
They not disapprove when you appland.

DIV1.HEAD: BOOKS Printed for Bernard Lintot, at the Middle-Temple Gate in Fleetstreet.

The Double Copy-Book: Publish'd by the late Sir Charles Cottrel. Price s. 6d.
Poems on several Occasions; together with the Song of the Three Children paraphras'd. Price 3 s.

Love and Business; in a Collection of occasionary Verse, and Episto∣lary Prose, the like not hitherto publish'd. A Discourse likewise on Co∣medy, in reference to the English Stage. Written by Mr. Farquar. Price 2s.
Fables Moral and Political, with large Explications, translated from the Dutch. In two Vol. Price 10 s.
Tland▪s Works in two Volumes. Price 6 s. Gilt on the Back.
The Dissertator, a Poem in Burlesque. Price 6d.
ove's last Shift, or the Fool in Fashion. By Mr. Cibber, Price 1s. 6d.
Tnbridge Walks, or the Yeoman of Kent. Price 1s. 6d.
The Inconstant, or the way to win him. Price 1s. 6d.
The Modish Husband, Pr. 1 6d. The Twin Rivals. Price 1s. 6d.
The Jew of Venice. A Comedy. Pr. 1 s. The Double Distress. Price 1s▪
Hytermestra, or Lve in Tears. By Robert Owen Esq; Price 1s. 6d.
The old mode and the New, or Country Miss with her Furbeloc. By Mr. D▪rey. Price 1s. 6d.
Love's Contrivance, or Le Medicine Malgre Lui. 1 s. 6d.
The Historical, Geographical, and Poetical Dictionary, in 2 Vol. 15 s.
